## \#44 Posted by: mason Posted at: 2016-10-20T23:51:44.329Z Reads: 707

```
you will want a 36/14 pulley gearing ratio. buy either [this](diy-electric-skateboard-kits-parts/36t-abec-drive-pulley-belt-combo-kit/) or [this](http://www.enertionboards.com/electric-skateboard-parts/12mm-wide-pulley-drive-hub-kit/)
motor mounts depend on the trucks you use. I would go with caliber trucks and get either [this](http://www.enertionboards.com/electric-skateboard-parts/carbon-fiber-motor-mount-enertion/) or [this](diy-electric-skateboard-kits-parts/single-bolt-on-motor-mount-only/)
get either a 170kv, 190kv, or 149kv motor. higher kv = more speed but less torque.
```

## \#53 Posted by: Jinra Posted at: 2016-10-24T23:22:09.700Z Reads: 628

```
Hybrid in what sense? Have 1 motor run sensored while the other motor doesn't? Or do you mean hybrid mode in the VESC. When I say you should use sensors, I mean you should use hybrid mode if you have a VESC.

If you're using a car ESC, running sensors at high speeds is inefficient and leaves your motors pretty toasty. I'd recommend running sensorless if you're using a standard car ESC.

## \#145 Posted by: osbor Posted at: 2017-01-29T04:31:47.603Z Reads: 297

```
watt hours is a better indicator
you get watt hours by multiplying the total pack voltage (6s is 6x3.6= if you're using lipos, 21.6 volts) by the amp hours (6000mah is 6ah) to get watt hours. and 10 watt hours roughly equals 1km of range

so! assuming the cells are all 3000mah individually...
6s4p is 21.6volts x (3Ah x 4parallel) = 21.6x12 = 259 watt hours = ~25km range
6s3p is 19.4km
6s2p is 12.9km
6s1p is 6.4km
```

## \#147 Posted by: NickTheDude Posted at: 2017-01-29T04:36:54.678Z Reads: 295

```
Series will add the voltage, parallel will add the amp hours and discharge rate. For the VESC higher voltages are definitely recommended depending on your kV, and hub motors generally have issues with heat dissipation so raising the voltage should lower the amps and heat, however how heat in a motor is generated seems to be debatable.

In series you would have 12S * 3Ah = 133.2Wh with 20C discharge and in parallel you would have 6S * 6Ah = 133.2Wh with a 40C discharge rate. Since lipos are capable of discharging high currents they generally do not need to be wired in parallel, your pack in series should be capable of 60A continuous and 120 in parallel. Li-ion packs need to have cells in parallel since their discharge rates are much lower (eg. 20A continuous for Samsung 25R cells).
```

## \#156 Posted by: osbor Posted at: 2017-01-29T05:43:46.128Z Reads: 266

```
speed is based on the number of cells in series
you use parallel to add range on that speed
its not like adding more in parallel drops your speed

so a 6s4p is slow but lasts a while (24 total cells)
a 10s4p (40 total cells) is faster and lasts a while as well

i guess another analogy would be like cylinders. as you add cylinders you get more powah, and parallel is adding more gas tanks
```

## \#167 Posted by: rpn314 Posted at: 2017-02-05T00:09:58.955Z Reads: 295

```
[quote="osbor, post:163, topic:9559, full:true"]
oh that does look nice, although pretty basic interface (battery read out and you can flash some canned user profiles like beginner and advanced). but....i didn't think the vsc had a bluetooth module on board? does that need to be added?
[/quote]

With the bluduino, it would be straight forward (though not easy). VESC has UART, and I'm pretty sure bluduino does as well, so you'd just need to interface with that and then bluetooth to the phone. Probably a little more work than it's worth, especially since there's a few good apps being developed around here that can interface with simple bluetooth chips.

[quote="smurf, post:166, topic:9559, full:true"]
What's the right gauge wire for BMS balance wires?
[/quote]

I'm not sure there's a specific BMS wire gauge size. I'd say around 24 gauge or so would be fine

[quote="jackmckill, post:165, topic:9559, full:true"]
Can someone explained batteries to me? Or point me in the right direction to resources that explain what to look for in a battery? I'm not understanding what 12s4p means vs 10s3p for example. What do those letters/numbers mean, and how does it effect the performance of the board? Thanks
[/quote]

12s4p means 12 cells in series (end to end) and 4 in parallel (next to each other). think 12 x 4 grid = 48 cells. 10s3p just means 10 in series and 3 in parallel. Higher series number means more cells end to end and thus a higher voltage. Higher parallel number means more cells across and longer runtime (for the same series count)
```

## \#174 Posted by: rpn314 Posted at: 2017-02-28T18:22:22.656Z Reads: 267

```
Getting from Asia isn't necessarily a bad thing, but you have to be really careful about quality. It's definitely a false sense of saving money as you'll get something, it will likely break, and you'll have to replace it costing even more.

With that said, I don't see any obvious issues with that motor, but I would encourage you to try and find a European reseller of a proven motor. I don't know much about the resellers over there, but you can start here: http://eu.electric-skateboard.market/

I would caution you away from that ESC. The VESC is the favorite here because it's extremely robust and can handle what we're doing with them. There's a few car ESCs that have been used without many issues, but I would not recommend any boat ESC.
```

## \#190 Posted by: mmaner Posted at: 2017-03-13T13:16:35.253Z Reads: 223

```
[quote="VikasG, post:189, topic:9559"]
would a 140Kv motor that is 6355 have less torque than a 140Kv motor that is 6374
[/quote]

The short answer is Yes, the long answer is that the 6374 is more efficient so uses the available Volts & Amps with less waste and less heat giving you a better running motor and therefore more torque, and product life, in the long run.

## \#263 Posted by: ElskerShadow Posted at: 2017-04-20T07:26:01.948Z Reads: 187

```
Noob question : why my little power bank is 30000 mah and my 10S3P is 7500 mah ? While being much bigger
```

---
## \#264 Posted by: TarzanHBK Posted at: 2017-04-20T07:43:39.724Z Reads: 198

```
a battery can have huge capacity in trade for low discharge or low capacity therefore high discharge, or a mix of both.
A powerbank needs high capacity and only really low discharge. So you might have 8 cells in parallel to get the 30ah.
In your board you have more cells in series to get the 10s (36V) and only 3 in parallel. 2500mah x 3 = 7500mah.
```

---
## \#265 Posted by: ElskerShadow Posted at: 2017-04-20T12:47:04.457Z Reads: 184

```
Thank you for the head up ! So could you tell me how much wh there's in a 30000 mah powerbank vs the 260 wh of a 7500 10S3p

The real capacity is wh ? Not mah ? I don't clearly know what's the difference
```

---
## \#266 Posted by: TarzanHBK Posted at: 2017-04-20T14:55:32.924Z Reads: 193

```
I assume there are 8 3,7V 18650 batteries in parallel in your powerbank. So 3,7V x 30ah = 111 Wh
10S3p with 7,5 ah = 36V x 7,5ah = 270 Wh
Watthours is the right term if you wanna know how much energy is stored in a pack.
Amphours tells you how much hours a battery is able to deliver 1 Amp. So the Volts are missing here to tell you somehing about the energy.
```

## \#299 Posted by: anorak234 Posted at: 2017-06-12T06:02:22.755Z Reads: 186

```
Don't run 5s. Run them in series for 10s. And get a 10s BMS from either bestech or supower

Reasons:
Higher voltage -> better efficiency/less amps -> more range 

5s is slow af and won't pull any hills

And charging at 10A will kill the batteries. Charge them at 2A or 4A
```

## \#329 Posted by: wafflejock Posted at: 2017-06-24T23:39:09.215Z Reads: 192

```
With the pulley ratio or any sort of gear ratio like that you are trading off speed for torque or vice versa.  If all you care about is torque and going fast doesn't matter then you just want a ratio between the teeth on the motor and teeth on the wheel to be a smaller fraction or larger number of difference in teeth... 10T on the motor and 30T on the wheel means the motor needs to turn 3 times for every full rotation of the wheel (driving pulley moves 10 teeth per turn, need to move 30 teeth of distance to rotate the driven pulley on the wheel), a 10T : 40T ratio means 1:4 or 4 times the turns on the small pulley to turn the big pulley.  For that last example you get a 4 times reduction in the speed and a 4 times increase in the torque, instead of moving 1 lb 1 inch you can move 4 lbs 1/4inch and not change the motor.  Basic point being if speed isn't a requirement just go with the highest ratio that seems reasonable and you can find parts for and you'll get the most push out of the motor for hill climbing.  Since you mentioned it's for a project if you're doing something remotely controlled you'd want to definitely have more traction than you would have on a regular skateboard, you might also want to consider just using stepper motors instead of RC style high speed motors since the drivers will be cheaper and keeping tight control of the steering with one stepper driving each side will be easier.
```

## \#337 Posted by: wafflejock Posted at: 2017-07-10T23:42:16.360Z Reads: 174

```
In theory they would be the same assuming they have the same power delivered and same efficiency.  My guess is in practice since you have a shaft held in place by bearings being rotated at higher speed means more loss due to friction (also mosfets and mosfet driver chips are switching at a higher speed).  If you see two motors with the same kv but one has a higher max wattage then it can handle more current and/or volts so it has larger wires for the windings in the stator and larger magnets in most cases (barring better design or build quality and components).  Geargenerator.com is a pretty cool page for messing with gear ratios, also a few esk8 calculators out there.
```

## \#360 Posted by: wafflejock Posted at: 2017-07-17T04:33:21.061Z Reads: 141

```
Yeah I was able to see all the noise on the line with an oscilloscope but on the PPM display it just seemed to make the values come through a bit jerky and if I slammed it on full brakes and full acceleration quickly enough while bench testing I could force it to lock up.  When it's under load you'll be pulling more amps and therefore making more electrical noise, but could also just be a loose connection between the receiver and VESC, is the connection soldered? if not would suggest putting a dab of hot glue around the JST connector to hold it into the VESC well to eliminate that from possible issues.  Would be good when it cuts out to see if your receiver still has power or if the VESC itself is resetting or just the receiver (or neither and it just lost signal between the controller and receiver).

---

Edit could also just solder the receiver connection to the VESC to be sure that connection is staying solid (probably good to just solder the wires directly to the receiver pins and cover with heatshrink to avoid needing to remove the male header pins)
```

Even a hair dryer would work. You don't need much heat.

```
Question about BMS and amp. 
I want to buy a cheap BMS only for charging 10s battery with Samsung 30Q batteries.
My concern is on which BMS should I go in terms of amp rating?
I use x2 6355 200kv motors and x2 VESCS, they are configured to motor max of 50A (each).
Do I need to use a BMS of 50A and above, or it doesn't really matter?
```

---
## \#393 Posted by: darkkevind Posted at: 2017-08-31T13:53:14.499Z Reads: 137

```
If you're using the BMS only for charge and not discharge, you can go with whatever Amp rated BMS you like. As long as the charge A rating fits your needs you're fine to go with 2A charge, 5 or 10A discharge because you will be bypassing the discharge anyway.

You need an ESC that has programmable cut-off voltages though, otherwise you may over discharge your cells.
```

---
## \#394 Posted by: TarzanHBK Posted at: 2017-08-31T13:53:41.191Z Reads: 137

```
If you´re only using a BMS for charging you only have to take care of that value, it doesn´t matter how much the discharging rating is, because you´re not using it ;)
```

## \#430 Posted by: krloz Posted at: 2017-12-10T09:16:45.259Z Reads: 148

```
Its kind of both.  You're psu needs to provide enough watts (VxAmps) to power the rate you are charging (batteryV x charging amps) plus the power losses. If you don't have a big enough psu you can try what you have and if the imax triggers the low voltage alarm, reset and set again to charge at lower amps.
What are the specs of your psu and batteries you want to charge??
```

## \#462 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-01-18T09:53:45.881Z Reads: 139

```
I don't want to hear any "person X did it and it's okay"  @TarzanHBK  I even said in my post lots of people do it.

That doesn't change at all the fact that you you are running the components on the edge of failure (into a reactive load, at that) and nearly every single piece of electronics you use in your life has at least a 40% margin of error.  And those are all pieces of electronics that won't throw you jaw-first into the street if they fail or kill your brakes at the top a huge hill.  It's just not worth it.  It's also a very expensive component if it fails.

Even at 10S we're running with a smaller margin than that.  At 12S, the margin is tiny and at 13S there is no margin at all, you're running at - or over - the rated limits of the components.  8S is actually the sweet spot for rock-solid dependability.

So my point still stands.  I don't recommend running 12S with a VESC.  If you don't value your body or your belongings, feel free to do it.  But I still can't recommend it.

Yeah, people do it.  People also [eat swords](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=glzMLZ6BaUo).  I don't recommend that, either.
```

## \#482 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-02-12T06:51:51.589Z Reads: 136

```
[quote="ZackoryCramer, post:476, topic:9559"]
Hello! :alien: If I am building a one layer 12s4p like this:

IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII

IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII

with the nickel strips connected in a snake pattern, should I use 3 or 4 layers of strips of the top and bottom ends? :thinking: The cells are sam. 30q and strips are 8 x .1mm
[/quote]
I don't know what you mean by "snake pattern" but you need to connect them this way, that way if any of them short together in the middle it doesn't cause a fire because they're already attached together there anyway
```
____ ____*____ ____*____ ____*____
IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII
____ ____ ____ ____ ____ ____ ____
IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII IIII
____*____ ____*____ ____*____ ____
```

Also connect the nickel with 10AWG silicone-insulated wire where the stars are so if the battery flexes it won't pop the welds

Also I only recommend 10S if you're using VESC
```

## \#528 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-03-19T20:27:53.282Z Reads: 112

```
For electric skateboards, bearing choice is nowhere near as important as it is for push boards.  You basically have 2 routes to take -- ceramic for resisting corrosion in brine and water, or normal steel.  Paying for high-quality bearings is almost a waste of money -- because you can either put the extra money into the drivetrain, where the ROI will be much, much, much, much higher, or just replace them when they are worn-out.  We don't need slick and smooth bearings to get us rolling further, because we have motors for that, and they are a few orders of magnitude more effective.
```

## \#540 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-03-20T00:18:04.027Z Reads: 133

```
[quote="koralle, post:537, topic:9559"]
Ok maybe this thread is a safe haven for the following predicament I find myself in:

What I often find: Posts of people mentioning that they fried their Vescs - including Focboxes - especially by setting them up wrong somehow.

What I can not find: A bulletproof step by step tutorial on how exactly to setup/connect two Focboxes for the first time with canbus for dual drive without messing up.

Can someone please help :blush:
[/quote]

The word "bulletproof" included in your question means that...
...you don't use CANBUS.

Use 2 radio receivers so both VESCs are only connected via the battery wires and via radio waves.  Basically so it's impossible to have a ground loop.

If you want to use CANBUS, "bulletproof" is definitely not the word I would use.
```

## \#568 Posted by: longhairedboy Posted at: 2018-04-05T18:05:27.228Z Reads: 145

```
[quote="macncheese, post:564, topic:9559"]
Is it possible and ok to use a 10s4p for this motor. I have dual motors. Also for more range can/should I do (2) 10s4p. I use this for off road, lots of starts & stops.
[/quote]

Yes, those motors work fine at 10S. However, the 4P is not going to give you  a lot of range. Assuming you're using 30Q cells, and the boards that these motors come on never do, you're going to want at minimum a 6P if you want any range. A 10S8P would actually be ideal for these monsters. 

YEs its only an 800 watt motor but hold onto your ass. They throw out a ton of torque and with twin motors you can easily grab a side and throw grass everywhere. You need a P count that can deal with that. 

If you're building your own pack, get a 100amp BMS for this or bigger.

Total count last i looked was about five of these big Tronix boards in my shop right now, mostly in parts and pieces with only one mostly put together and functioning. We've been over-volting and abusing them for a customer of ours.
```

## \#579 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-04-10T20:15:15.804Z Reads: 137

```
[quote="Deckoz, post:578, topic:9559"]
hobby
[/quote]

Some of us use these the exact same way you use a car.  Calling this a hobby is counterproductive to all of us.  

That's like calling driving cars a hobby because a few people build muscle cars in their garage.  If it's perceived as a hobby by laymen, it's much easier to ban and regulate because it's perceived as "optional".  For me, it's not optional.  I need this to get groceries, go to work, and to live my life to its fullest.  When you call it a hobby, it helps to alter public perception which hurts me in tiny ways.  Each time it's called a hobby it helps to shift the perception into "this is something we can ban if they piss us off".   Whereas, for example, cars -- you think if it was a hobby it wouldn't be banned?  Car accidents are deadly and if that was a hobby the general public would ban it immediately because it's too dangerous to have these steel death machines flying around all over the place.  So let's do ourselves a favor and just try to avoid using the word hobby.  For some, it may be, but for others, it's definitely not -- and for laymen that don't know the difference, the word "hobby" means "we can outlaw this".

This is all.
```

## \#598 Posted by: Deckoz Posted at: 2018-04-11T16:27:09.506Z Reads: 142

```
1. Plug it into a 3 or 4s lipo(I always start with low voltage)
2. Upgrade to ackmaniac 2.54 or 3.100 firmware...if you desire
3. Perform a read configuration on the motor side and app side
4. Set up canbus and IDs if your using it
5. Set amperage limits and voltage limits on motor general
6. Perform a motor config in bldc or foc
6.  Write motor configuration
7. Go-to the app tab, setup your control type(ppm, ppm & uart, or nunchuck etc)
8. Go-to your control type tab ie ppm, setup your ppm endpoints and center. And failsafe.
9. Pick your motor control type in your app control type tab (ie on the ppm tab, select current no reverse, or current with reverse etc)
10. Write app configuration.

Plug in a real Battery, test it, go ride. There are detailed instructions for each step scattered around the forum, but this should be a good starting place...
```

## \#635 Posted by: mmaner Posted at: 2018-04-19T20:52:09.341Z Reads: 117

```
[quote="DevinG, post:634, topic:9559"]
Is it Safe to rest you vesc on top of batteries?
[/quote]

I wouldn't, heat is only one of the issues.  The other concern that I would have would be height.  With a single stack battery pack with VESC's on top, that's close to 2 inches. ## \#708 Posted by: Deckoz Posted at: 2018-04-25T20:49:36.419Z Reads: 148

```
[quote="cypa9904, post:695, topic:9559, full:true"]
Can sb explain me how is works? (And the difference between batt max 20 and 40?)

Batt max is f.ex 30A, while motor max may be even 80A. I do not get it.
[/quote]

Duty cycle. 

Let's setup an example.
10s2p 30q, nominal 36v, with an 40a constant current output

Your batt max is 40a
Your motor max is 80a

You battery can provide 36v * 40A = 1440Watts

Duty cycle in simple terms is a percentage of work, from the main power source. For example 25% duty of 36v = 9v

(36v * 0.25 duty) * 80 motor amps = 720watts

Your battery can only provide 1440 watts
1440W/80a = 18v or 50% duty

36v * 0.5 duty = 18v

So above 50% duty, the motor max amperage will drop, to to your battery max limit

1440W/(36v * 0.51 duty) = 78.43A motor max
1440W/(36v * 0.52 duty) = 76.92A motor max

Etc...

#duty-cycle
#peakwatts
#motorpower
#voltage
```

## \#710 Posted by: Deckoz Posted at: 2018-04-25T21:52:37.075Z Reads: 135

```
[quote="briman05, post:709, topic:9559, full:true"]
How many constant current amps is a 10s4p of 30q batteries.
[/quote]

30q is 15A rated. But tested to be 20 provided it's kept below 80c.

So manufacturer
15A*4p=60

Tested rating (mooch)
20a*4p=80

Pick your poison
```

## \#799 Posted by: wafflejock Posted at: 2018-05-07T23:17:54.917Z Reads: 120

```
You're more likely to damage the cells than the ESC, most Esk8 setups using 18650 cells like your drill uses with have them in parallel so no single cell is having to deliver all the amps that are flowing out the battery and into the ESC and motor.  Say the cells in there can do 20A at peak for a few moments without frying out or dropping so much in voltage they die quickly... if you are pulling more like 30-40A (or trying to) then you are going to have major problems with the battery.  If you find the max amperage of the cells and limit the amperage in the VESC tool then there shouldn't be any issues aside from possibly needing to push start or not having enough power to climb hills or push against the wind.
```

## \#877 Posted by: longhairedboy Posted at: 2018-05-16T19:14:00.446Z Reads: 142

```
add to that... 

* BMS
* balance lead/connectors if they don't come with the BMS
* mosfet board (vedder switch or other type) if the BMS doesn't have one built in to plug your on-off switch into
* wire strippers/cutters

Kapton tape is great for its dielectric properties but if you want to keep wires in place with a vengence (and if you don't need a high dielectric tape in that particular location ) before you slip the whole pack into the shrink tube, i would get a roll of Gorilla tape. I have started using it along the nickel edges to add padding to it before running balance leads down the side when i need to, and small strips to neatly tie down the balance leads, and also to add some toughness/padding to the total package.
```

## \#901 Posted by: TarzanHBK Posted at: 2018-05-17T11:08:38.048Z Reads: 122

```
These are bleeding resistors and this is how a BMS works in most cases.
Every resitor is for one cell/cellpair and if the first cellpair is full, it starts bleeding the energy off in heat, while other cells are still charging. The more cells are full, the hotter it gets, because the more resistors do their job.
This process runs until every cell is full :slight_smile:
```

---

## \#978 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-05-30T14:33:14.626Z Reads: 117

```
That's not going to work.  You could use 24AWG for charging at 1.5A but I still recommend 22AWG silicone-insulated.  26AWG is too small.  Also if charging at 1.5A you could put a 2A car fuse on that also

Between BMS and ESC you want to use 12AWG minimum and 10AWG is even better, but for single motor, 12 is probably okay.  14 or smaller is not okay and 18 will melt within seconds
```

## \#980 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-05-30T16:13:19.970Z Reads: 115

```
That is the best way to run the nickel connections.

Any series connection must be 10AWG or 12AWG because it will carry the full pack current.  Use super-stranded, silicone-insulated wire.

Also remember that after you make it, you will be picking it up and bashing it against a concrete wall wheels-first as hard as you can for 30 minutes.  So make it able to withstand that.  Well, you won't be doing that, but you'll be riding it which has exactly the same effect on the stuff inside
```

## \#1009 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-06-01T05:41:25.582Z Reads: 121

```
All the cells need to be at EXACTLY the same voltage when you make the parallel packs.  It's a lot better if they are all at the same voltage. They can't be off a tenth of a volt and that's just okay, they need to be the same.

Whether they are 3.57V or 4.12V is not as important, as long as they are all the same.  Also, 30Q cells need to be kept between 3V and 4.22V at all times.

Typically the easiest way to make them all the same is to charge them all on the same charger if you have a 1S charger.  Otherwise you will need to do it manually by bringing the higher cells down - to match the lowest cell - with an automotive incandescent light bulb.
```

## \#1017 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-06-03T03:01:48.988Z Reads: 112

```
If you use a resistor to bottom-balance the cells you need to select the proper resistance to get it done in less than an eternity.  So for example

Assuming you want to use a 0.25 watt through-hole resistor

and assuming the biggest difference in your cells are off by 0.31V (like 3.90V and 3.59V for example)

then using the R = VV/P gives you R = (0.31V) * (0.31V) / (0.25W) = 0.3844Ω

So then get some through-hole resistors at least 0.385Ω like [these 1Ω ones](https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/stackpole-electronics-inc/CF14JT1R00/CF14JT1R00CT-ND/1830305)
```

## \#1065 Posted by: Namasaki Posted at: 2018-06-06T17:29:00.388Z Reads: 102

```
[quote="J.Biggs, post:1062, topic:9559"]
So would bypassing the bms with five 2s 5000mah 90c lipos be dangerous to the dual focbox.
[/quote]

Absolutely Not!
Because the battery doesn’t determine system current. The Focbox controls battery and motor current separately. 
The higher the battery’s discharge rating, the better. 
Because higher discharge rating = less voltage sag and less heat and stress on the battery. 
And less voltage sag = more power and range.
```

Does your charger test internal resistance?

## \#1314 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2018-07-21T20:35:17.128Z Reads: 117

```
@banksta
You can't re purpose those  esc's from any of those boards.  They are factory set up for the application they are intended for.  There is no way to adjust settings at all.  Also the hub motor esc's are not compatible with belt drive systems.  DIYeboards sell a belt drive version of the same esc but I don't recommend using their mechanical belt drive system as its cheap and with belts you really need a strong reliable set up such as @torqueboards provides.   Don't be dragged into the false economy of diy you will regret it.  You can also purchase a power switch system which includes an anti spark from a number of vendors.
```

## \#1357 Posted by: wafflejock Posted at: 2018-07-30T18:54:57.324Z Reads: 121

```
The on/off switch appears to just be a regular rocker/toggle switch and should just have two pins on it when in the I position the two pins are closed/connected when in the O position the circuit is open/disconnected.  The BMS will need to have a place for using the switch if this will work so you'll need to look into the BMS documentation or with the vendor for how to add the power switch (since it's limited at 6A you wouldn't want to just connect it along the discharge path or it would likely cook while you're riding).  The barrel connectors are either positive center or negative center, easiest way to figure this out is just connect it to the power supply you'll use then check the voltage with a voltmeter off the pads/pins on the back of the barrel connector, if you probe it measuring voltage and it is a negative value then you have the black (negative) probe on the positive terminal (basically they are reversed if it's negative), if the value is positive then you have the black probe on the common/gnd and the red on the positive.

Good to use a voltmeter/multimeter in volt measuring mode and continuity checking mode to see what is connected to what or what polarity etc.
```

```
With li-ion, yes, as far as I know.
I know some commercial boards use fast charge such as the Raptor 2.

However for lipo's usually they have like a 'safe' charge of 1c. 

''While I agree, THERE IS NO DATA, to suggest that when using a high performance, computer controlled balance charger that the batteries suffer in ANY way as a function of charge rate. Remember, a state of the art LiPo can sustain a 30C discharge rate and peak of 60C. Asking it to handle a 3 or 4 or even 5C during the charge cycle is not a big request..... UNLESS, you just plug it in and hit it with high amperage via an old fashion charger.

High rate charging MUST be done with computer controlled balance chargers. You should not connect a LiPo to traditional charger and charge above 1C. Computer controlled chargers hit the LiPo pack hard early in the charge cycle then taper off as voltage and thus resistance builds. ''

https://www.helifreak.com/showthread.php?t=114780

## \#1516 Posted by: Andy87 Posted at: 2018-09-05T06:04:43.477Z Reads: 83

```
first of all, your first built will most likely be not your last built...
It´s an addiction ;) so don´t worry so much.
I wouldn´t cheap out quality components, so better go single with good quality products, than dual with cheap shitty crap.
If you once where driving dual, you don´t want to go back to single drive...
But, this does not mean that single drive will not give you enough power. If you get a 6374 or 6384 motor you will most likely get more torque than you need. 
Just make an easy calculation
Let´s say most 6374 motors rated to 3200W.
Standard VESC/Focbox (without special cooling cases) rated to 60A max current
you will run max 12s so 50.4V fully charged
to put all together you come up to 3000W which is quite a lot.
If you go dual and want the double power, you also need a battery which can handle double, so 120A constant, which is a lot a lot ;)
The advantage of dual is just that you split the load to two VESCs and two motors, which will let them run cooler and you will get a better break force for sure as there is more mass working in the motors.
```

If no, than mount your focbox with the heat sink outside of the enclosure, good airflow always better.

if you don´t push everything to the limits it will for sure not overheat, aaand in case it overheats, your vesc will reduce power output by it´s own till your components cooled down.

## \#1775 Posted by: Andy87 Posted at: 2018-09-22T10:21:16.011Z Reads: 93

```
I don’t use ack app but you can set this app up for single motor and dual.
What you have on your board and are the settings shown in the app for one or for two motors?
At 80 degree your vesc start the restrict your power output to not totally overhead.
If you set your bat max for single drive to 60a that can happen easily. 
Reduce the settings to 40a (35 if it’s a vesc with hw 4.12) or get a heatsink case from @Kug3lis if you have a focbox, than it should be ok.
Motor max i would also reduce to 60-80a

The speed is calculated by the settings you input in the app (depending on your gearing and wheel size)

The down part is the average usage of power, current etc. 
It’s calculate on the values recorded during your trip

## \#1848 Posted by: Andy87 Posted at: 2018-09-24T17:09:12.816Z Reads: 89

```
Yes it’s a 6mm shaft on the motor, so you will need a motor pulley with a 6mm bore too.
Something like this 
Schau, was ich auf AliExpress gefunden
https://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/b58nHKCS
But it’s for belts till 20mm width, so I guess you need a bit a smaller one.

All the equipment is for installing the motor to a plane or copter.
If you have a motor mount you will not need it.
Can you please double check that there is a o-ring on your shaft, which hold the can in position?
If yes than you definitely don’t need anything from this parts.

If you didn’t have a motor mount yet, make sure the one you buy fit to 5055 motors. Most of them made for 63xx motor and as they bigger they don’t fit to your motor.

The motor pulley you can fix with a scup screw and blue or red loctite, or only with green loctited.
```

## \#1954 Posted by: briman05 Posted at: 2018-10-05T17:25:24.370Z Reads: 104

```
a few things first you should always go with the grain of the wood never acrossed. Which is why it looks worse with the orbital sander cause it is spinning in a semi circle.  Every once in a while you get a piece of wood that has knots in it and they are a bitch because the grain goes around the knot.  Now as far as grit of sandpaper goes 220 is the general go to to sand in between either layers of paint or clear coat because it roughs up the surface enough for the layer on top to adhere to the layer on the bottom.  Now 220 is still rough as fuck in terms of sand paper on my builds I used 800-2000 grit.  Now as far as painting goes are you using a spray can or brush on. Spray will lay on smoother if you have a steady hand or a spray gun/spray paint handle to give you even pressure on the nozzle.  Brush on there is technique and type of brushes involved.  If you are really after the no brush strokes look you need a high quality brush like this  
https://www.purdy.com/products/brushes/nylox/nylox-sprig/
```

## \#1978 Posted by: Kug3lis Posted at: 2018-10-08T13:19:10.540Z Reads: 94

```
Ahm why you put resistors on balance leads? You balance out each pack to exact voltage and connect them in parallel and no output will be dumped anywhere... Everyone is using like that for ages no need to reinvent wheel. Plus resistor inline will make balancers see lower voltage than it is.

EDIT based on ned drawing, you still have path for current to flow from cells to one another, also main current will flow through main leads the moment you connect them together. BMS will not balance each parallel cell as separate cell but as single cell
```

## \#2014 Posted by: Andy87 Posted at: 2018-10-21T12:21:19.775Z Reads: 90

```
What you mean with max cut off?
There is only cut off start and end.
LiIon can be discharged till 2.5v per cell.
The standard settings with the ackmaniac sw are cut off start at 3v and cut off end at 2,8V.
If you set it to 3,2 and 3v it’s still a nice headroom till 2,5V. Try this settings and look if you get a better range. If no, than check you pack, maybe one cell or parallel group went bad.
```

## \#2132 Posted by: Andy87 Posted at: 2018-11-02T08:24:54.455Z Reads: 88

```
the problem with the jumper cable is, that you non the less need to connect and disconnect the wires each time you want to remove the enclosure. If you use mt60 connectors that would work, but with bullet connectors which you should cover with a extra heatshrink or electric tape after connected, it would be kind of time consuming.
you could place your unity in the enclosure as it´s only idk 180-200g if i remember right. with it you only need to disconnect the main power leads.
or 
you can place the phase holes to the total up of your enclosure, so that they open to the end of the enclosure.
if you use 5 or 10mm neopren tape instead of rubber to seal your electrics you can than just route your cables along the deck.
```

## \#2282 Posted by: Andy87 Posted at: 2018-11-18T06:11:44.275Z Reads: 105

```
Naaaah not so fast ☝️ I want you to understand what’s going on because it’s easy and a basic thing (sorry @dareno 🤪)
Long battery wires can cause an inductive voltage spike which could kill your vesc (you maybe know the specs for vescs say voltage spikes may not exceed 60V)
With this said, there are capacitors on each vesc and focbox. Capacitors work against induction caused voltage spikes. 
The longer the wires, the higher the spikes can be. The closer you run to the max voltage, the more likely is it that you fry something (12s instead of 10s).
There are some things you can do to lower the effect of induction 
Get extra capacitors to the ones you already have on the vesc/focbox 
Use bigger wires
Route the plus and minus wires as close as you can to each other.

Ok and lastly, as long as you around 50cm and don‘t use a 14s battery you should be good with the stock capacitors on your vesc
```

```
No, not really more work.
Just use 10awg (or 8awg if you have the space)
And don’t use 1m long cables and you should be good.

The capacitors would needed to be wired parallel to the ones you already have.

```

## \#2291 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2018-11-18T07:06:21.017Z Reads: 112

```
[quote="legend27, post:2289, topic:9559"]
When I charge my battery, the voltage rises a lot after I plug it in.
[/quote]

This is normal, until you start to approach the end of charge.

A "CC/CV" charge (aka - a lithium charger) starts in CC (Constant Current) mode which kicks up the voltage a lot [until desired current is achieved, printed on the charger], until voltage reaches a set level (usually 4.20V per cell) then it switches to Constant Voltage mode and holds there until current drops below some threshold
```

## \#2401 Posted by: Andy87 Posted at: 2018-12-04T10:07:39.376Z Reads: 104

```
In accordance with US electrical codes the max current for circuits utilizing 12 gauge wire is 20 Amps. However, 12 gauge copper wire is capable of handling much higher currents. There is something called fusing current, the current at which a wire will melt. For 12 gauge copper it is about 235 Amps.
```

## \#2461 Posted by: Eboosted Posted at: 2018-12-08T18:17:16.190Z Reads: 91

```
I lowered the EOC voltage but soon after that the charger stopped charging, not working anymore.

Why do you need to lower EOC voltage? A few reasons are:

1. Your bms is cutting power when battery is full and you brake
Fix: bypass your bms for discharge 

2. You want to increase the lifespan of the battery.
Fix: use the battery at it's maximum capacity, the lifespan is already pretty high

3. You want to lower a 12s to 10s charge
Fix: get a new charger, no charger could go down that much
```

## \#2512 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2018-12-12T09:07:02.904Z Reads: 91

```
[quote="topherbarnett, post:379, topic:9559"]
When you guys mount your batteries and ESCs, do you stick them to the deck or to the enclosure? What’s your favorite mounting method for electronics? Pics would be helpful!
[/quote]

Tomato tomate o  to be honest.  Its about ease of construction.  You can set up on the deck a lot easier than on the enclosure.  You can get it all solid with velcro and use the high grip stuff not cheap rubbish then foam the enclosure so it all holds in there with no movement at all.  Vibration is the enemy with esk8.  It destroys everything eventually so take it away.  Make sure everything is solid connection wise too.  Double up the shrink over bullets and basically remove anything that can potentially fail.  It will still fail but minimising the risk is the best way to start,  Good luck.
```

## \#2539 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2018-12-15T00:30:03.566Z Reads: 83

```
You will have an effect called cogging.  Its a shuddering on start up. The esc does not know the position of the motor. Thats what hall sensors do.  Once the motor is moving it stops.  It is very slight and the tiniest movement will smooth it out.  As much as a hip flick to move.  Where it becomes problematic is on hills but a quick push and you're good.  Going balls out from a start stops it too.
```

Doesn't matter what the application is, you don't want to jam your things full of loctite. A little bit goes a long way. It isn't super glue where it'll lose its effectiveness but it doesn't add any extra benefits. In fact, if you ever need to take the screws out, you'll have a harder time.

```

---
## \#2696 Posted by: rich Posted at: 2018-12-25T12:32:19.169Z Reads: 84

```
[quote="mutantbass, post:2695, topic:9559"]
B1+ wire goes to the positive pack nearest the total battery negative?
[/quote]

Yes, a battery always starts with the negative side, so B1+ is the positive pole of parallel pack #1 and so on. B10+ is pack #10 and the same as your positive pole of your whole battery pack. 

When you finished wiring measure the voltages first. Mulltimeter negative on battery negative and with the positive start at B1+, then B2+, B3+...... If the voltage is rising in cell voltage steps (e.g. 3.6V) then you are golden.

Always connect negative pole of your battery to B- of the BMS **before** you plug in the balance cables!
```

```
[quote="directC, post:2724, topic:9559"]
Why must we use fishpaper when building batteries?
[/quote]

Fishpaper protects against vibrations because lots of things like tape and foam wear through under vibration and things will short out.  Fishpaper is better at dealing with vibrations and keeping things insulated.  145ptags.com is a great place to find it
```

## \#2764 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2018-12-28T22:20:20.848Z Reads: 82

```
Realistically speaking that battery is far too small for a mountainboard.  With no idea what cells you have then you would have to err on the side of caution when setting battery max and at 2p the power will be very underwhelming.  If you have run the vesc at factory settings right out of the box then the bms is probably cutting the board off when you put it under pressure.  If it is set up charge only then the battery is just sagging.  My advice would be to upgrade the battery to decent 30q cells at a minimum of 4p
I don't feel comfortable advising you on settings for a pack I know nothing about so sorry I can't be more help.  Good luck.
```

## \#2918 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-01T04:36:23.089Z Reads: 76

```
Much of soldering is all about attention to a detail.  That detail is the meniscus -- the place where the surface of a liquid meets a solid and it bends -- you can usually tell just from that whether it is a good solder joint or not.

ALWAYS, ALWAYS try to pull the wire off with your hand after it cools.  If you can yank it off, then it was no good anyway and it's going to fail.  (If you yank yank it off that does not mean it's okay though)
```

***D*** the horizontal surface was hot enough but the vertical one was not, and the solder itself was heated instead of the part

## \#2956 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-02T20:19:08.981Z Reads: 79

```
Amps aren't something that are pushed, they are pulled.  Voltage is pushed.

So it outputs 5V, and is capable of supplying a lot of amperage, if drawn.  But with no load the amperage will be zero, while the voltage will still be 5.

Amperes are "A",  "a" means "atto" and is a metric prefix.

What do you need the 3V 300mA for?  It's always possible to use a few diode drops to use the 5V supply for that, but it depends what you need it for.
```

## \#2960 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-03T01:43:43.229Z Reads: 78

```
Sometimes it is and sometimes it doesn't have to be.  Some BMS don't have B0, in that case you must use B-.  Also if you discharge through the BMS you must run large gauge wire to B-.  It all depends.  That's the way I like to wire it with a BMS that has B0

Also that way all your charge current is going through B0 so make sure it's 22AWG or bigger for 4A charge and 24AWG or bigger for 2A charge.

Also always put a 5A or 7.5A or 10A fuse on the charge jack
```

```
ERPM is electronic Revolutions per minute. It deals with your motors spinning. Basically if you have a 10s you will want around a 190 kv as a 270 kv erpm will be to high for the vesc to handle with the 10s for the battery. There is a thread about selecting the right motor kv.

With you're configuration the ERPM would be 13 (batteries in series) * 4.2 (Volts of fully charged battery) * 190 (kv of motor) * 7 (likely number of poles in motor) = 72618. A good rule of thumb is to be under 60,000.
Edit: This is all from information I've gotten on the forum and not first hand.
```

## \#3201 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-08T04:36:36.142Z Reads: 70

```
Don't get those pulleys, they are 3M.  You want HTD-5M and if it doesn't say that, then it's probably not good

Those teeth are too small and it's also not compatible with anything else in the market so if your belt skips, you have to replace everything instead of one thing.  Also the small teeth skip easier.

That's a good mount and remote

That motor isn't sensored which means you will have to kick-push once before you hit the throttle.  But folks say they're good motors.  I never had one because they aren't sensored.
```

## \#3260 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2019-01-09T19:04:19.894Z Reads: 73

```
For wiring vesc batteries etc.

14AWG: 32A continuous, ~65A peak &lt; 10s
12AWG: 41A continuous, ~80A peak &lt; 10s
10AWG: 55A continuous, ~110A peak &lt; 10s   
8AWG: 73A continuous, ~150A peak &lt; 10s
6AWG: 101A continuous, ~200A peak &lt; 10s

And for charging and balance leads etc

26AWG: 2.2A continuous
24AWG: 3.5A continuous
22AWG: 7A continuous &lt;-- usually this one
20AWG: 11A continuous
18AWG: 16A continuous
16AWG: 22A continuous

All cables should be silicon sleeved and multi strand.
Like the ones you will find in here along with shrink tube connectors etc.  Happy hunting
 https://hobbyking.com/en_us/workbench/hardware.html
```

## \#3308 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-11T02:22:01.406Z Reads: 77

```
Protip: @buildityourself also plug the two halves together when you solder to them.  Being plugged-in keeps the pins straight while they get hot enough to melt nylon 

So that means you need an extra pair above and beyond the ones that will go in your build.  Also the extra pair is insurance if you mess one up, you can use the messed-up one as your holder.  Kind of [like this messed up one](https://www.electric-skateboard.builders/t/how-to-anti-spark-xt-90-loop-key/204/104?u=b264) I accidentally built wrong, so now I just use it to hold ones that I am soldering on to keep the pins straight.
```

## \#3333 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-12T02:37:36.996Z Reads: 79

```
[quote="Ian-mountainboard, post:3328, topic:9559, full:true"]
what gauge wire should i go with for my 10s 5p battery pack.
[/quote]

Depends if you want to drive 1 motor or 2 motors. 

1 motor:
internal series connections: 10AWG or dual 14AWG
external wiring: 12AWG

2 motors:
internal series connections: dual 12AWG
external wiring: 10AWG


This is just a rough idea and depends on lots of different things
```

## \#3391 Posted by: kalebludlow Posted at: 2019-01-13T18:21:18.057Z Reads: 83

```
![3d06f5425144940f41744b6564dc7c7b79af6894_1_375x500|375x500](upload://nRVMMf82dbzO3TdhLI2oTnVV8Of.jpeg) 

So first get a pair of needle nose pliers and insert them into the C adapter’s like this

![e801542a2f736b4cca30dd5b263db3fcc57dc094_1_375x500|375x500](upload://m5kANAwx7SJODhIWK68gh1XPLBe.jpeg) 

Then twist them so it’s like this, this should now fit on the truck. If it doesn’t then just shove the pliers further down at the first step

![4a400ea8c81f7de16739c62994d4be597c181aaa_1_375x500|375x500](upload://qGYVFmUZDjAYcoJvS2vd7PtrcGI.jpeg) 

On the clamp, the screw has two sides it can go into, you want to insert the screw into the threaded side first

![edab133aaefd888b1b6b7854bc3acb3a61e82073_1_375x500|375x500](upload://b4RXjOKIN8PbO3ChIiZdLsm9LlH.jpeg) 

Like this

![b841cfc3acfcd9231d40cacf8fe0bcd0c9f91cb9_1_375x500|375x500](upload://yRvkQr7gPoIXv03SjCR8ZVnkmxb.jpeg) 

Then when your near filling the gap get a piece of strong metal (I use the metal ring thing from the front of my dicky pulley) then tighten the screw until it bends the metal out

![168f94b557b919aae556ccd7235f261fc37d7476_1_375x500|375x500](upload://h2IKl5MVe6Zhf79JGXp03qWz1AK.jpeg) 

Then just put it in the truck and remove the screw and you’re all good, just when using that extra piece of metal make sure it isn’t obstructing the part where the truck goes into


This is my method for getting these mounts on. Its yet to fail me
```

## \#3495 Posted by: Narnash Posted at: 2019-01-15T15:41:21.447Z Reads: 74

```
Check the voltage of each cell on the balance plug (If your charger doesn't have a measuring option), most likely one of the cells is deep discharged to the point where the charger says it's unsafe to charge the battery.
You may be able to charge the deep discharged cell (slowly) up again, right to the point where the charger accepts to balance charge the whole battery. Other option would be to disassemble the the battery removing the bad cell and to reuse the left ones but nothing for LiPo noobs basicly.

BTW does the LiPo look puffed or anything?
```

## \#3497 Posted by: Narnash Posted at: 2019-01-15T15:56:31.434Z Reads: 76

```
Well If you can determine that one of the cells in the battery is puffed up than this specific cell in the pack is basicly dead and/or unsafe to use. If the pack overall is only very slightly puffed and even more recovering over time you can use it but keep an eye on it (don't drain to much amps from it and do not use it when it's swelling again).

Either way you should check the voltage on each single cell in the battery pack (over the balance leads) and share them with us, if the whole battery is over discharged it's most likely not reuseable for esk8 (or any other high loads) and may need to go to your local recycling center.
```

## \#3510 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-15T20:15:37.853Z Reads: 84

```
@Mudders the 6mm / 0.25" tinned braided copper is good for 40A continuous.  And for wire,

For wiring vesc batteries etc.

14AWG: 32A continuous, ~65A peak &lt; 10s
12AWG: 41A continuous, ~80A peak &lt; 10s
10AWG: 55A continuous, ~110A peak &lt; 10s
8AWG: 73A continuous, ~150A peak &lt; 10s
6AWG: 101A continuous, ~200A peak &lt; 10s

And for charging and balance leads etc

26AWG: 2.2A continuous
24AWG: 3.5A continuous
22AWG: 7A continuous &lt;-- usually this one
20AWG: 11A continuous
18AWG: 16A continuous
16AWG: 22A continuous

All cables should be silicone insulated and super/fine stranded.

So for a single motor battery rated at 40A max, you can use one braid and 12AWG wire

For a dual motor battery rated at 55A continuous you can use dual 6mm braid and single 10AWG (or dual 14AWG) wire

Of course, it also matter what cells you use and what nickel...
```

## \#3524 Posted by: wafflejock Posted at: 2019-01-16T01:24:32.321Z Reads: 82

```
Sure @b264 has his own response but to give you an idea of insane settings.  If your battery max discharge is 60A probably set the battery max amperage in VESC to be something lower than this (like 40A) same for charging, don't push more than a few C at max for regen braking so as to not damage cells by pumping too much charge into them too quickly.  Make sure the voltage settings for the battery make sense in terms of max and soft/hard cut off values (minimums).  You could also limit eRPM but if you have a low enough kv*voltage (below 8,571 RPM assuming 14 pole motor or in any case under 60,000 eRPM), then it won't be an issue.

---

Also assumed you do motor calibration with no load on the motor and receiver setup so you can control your motor.
```

---
## \#3525 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-16T01:41:22.424Z Reads: 85

```
Yes, this.

[quote="wafflejock, post:3524, topic:9559"]
don’t push more than a few C at max for regen braking so as to not damage cells by pumping too much charge into them too quickly
[/quote]
3600C = Hz = 1 per second

That means if you have a 12Ah battery, for example purposes, don't regen ("battery minimum" setting) less than 1 - 2 C which in this case is -12A to -24A. Going less like -30C might harm your cells.  And I would even stay above -24A.

[quote="wafflejock, post:3524, topic:9559"]
Make sure the voltage settings for the battery make sense in terms of max and soft/hard cut off values (minimums).
[/quote]

This means like, for example if you have a lithium-ion battery, set cutoffs at 3.2V/cell and 3.4V/cell which for a 10S battery means "cutoff start" is 34.0V and "cutoff end" is 32.0V

If you have lithium-polymer or lithium iron phosphate or lithium titanate, the numbers will be different.

[quote="wafflejock, post:3524, topic:9559"]
You could also limit eRPM but if you have a low enough kv*voltage (below 8,571 RPM assuming 14 pole motor or in any case under 60,000 eRPM), then it won’t be an issue.
[/quote]

If you don't use a motor over 190kv, this won't be an issue with 10S systems.
```

## \#3550 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-01-16T08:56:05.131Z Reads: 77

```
@Bjork3n @J_Dizzle   If a key isn't an option, my recommendation would be to use a dremel tool or similar method to put a flat on the motor shaft, and then use a good quality setscrew. Don't use the cheap Chinese ones that are made of cheese, they will strip, and then you will cry. Get some good high-strength (grade 8 if imperial, grade 12.9 if metric) cup-point setscrews from somewhere like McMaster-Carr. They even sell them with threadlocker already applied. 

I do not recommend trying to stuff a setscrew into a keyway, because under significant force (like braking) the keyway has a good chance to deform, and thus become stuck in the pulley, even once you remove the screw. If you have a suitable flat, the setscrew has something to properly bite into, without fear of deforming the shaft and making it impossible to remove at a later date.

Loctite 648 is good, but like b264 said, it's better to have a physical attachment where it really matters most.
```

## \#3605 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-01-16T21:07:04.348Z Reads: 78

```
@Ian-mountainboard  I am of the school of thought that the BMS should have full authority, so my setups have always been wired for charge and discharge. Of course, this has the drawbacks that you need a physically large BMS to handle the high current we deal with, and if the BMS decides the battery is in danger or empty, you'll be unable to ride any further. 

On the other side of the fence, if you use a charge-only BMS, it can be physically smaller, and in an emergency you can mistreat the cells a little bit more than you normally would to get home. But if you're habitually inattentive, this can lead to reduced lifespan for your batteries, since the BMS has no way to stop you from doing damage.
```

## \#3661 Posted by: thisguyhere Posted at: 2019-01-17T21:59:41.386Z Reads: 70

```
4.35v that's over volt protection, like from a regen system attempting to pump more voltage than it's designed for.

given the right charger it'll never over-volt, right, 12s charger max voltage is 50.4v...so it can't go above that.  now...if someone's being funny and used a 60v cc/cv charger on a 12s or something, yea this bms will stop it at 4.35v, but don't do that.

anyway, in esk8 application does not apply since both upper and lower voltage cutoff is configurable via vesc.

and yes, charging to less than 4.2v yields longer cell life.  i've asked bestech if they can balance charge to 4.1v and was straight up denied.
```

## \#3748 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-20T20:48:24.682Z Reads: 74

```
Used laptop cells won't work.  They can't supply enough current, and you will kill them trying to pull that much from them.  The only way those will work is if you make something like a 6S20P battery with them.  That will work for an esk8.

At 2P deep, you need to set your "Battery Current Max" to like 5A which won't get you anywhere.  Otherwise your cells will sag so far they will die immediately.

There's no way you're getting 30mph+ from laptop cells.  You might be able to get 20mph if you do it correctly and you have at least 100 of them, and they are all good.
```

## \#3830 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-01-21T09:41:08.797Z Reads: 80

```
13s is the highest possible voltage a vesc can handle. 12s, being close to that, puts more stress on the vesc than 10s will, and thus people tend to have a somewhat higher failure rate with 12s than with 10s, especially with FOC, and especially with 4.xx hardware. That's what b264 means about fuckup space with 10s vs 12s.

In terms of advantages and disadvantages, assuming you keep all the same hardware (wheel size, pulley size, motor KV, etc) 12s will give you a ~20% higher top speed, but since 10s3p can supply more current and power than 12s2p, you'll get better range and acceleration with 10s. 

Boosted uses entirely different cells. They're a different size (26650 vs 18650) and a different cemestry (LiFePO4 vs NCA). Our batteries are much more energy-dense, but LiFePO4  has a higher cycle life and is safer.
```

## \#3844 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-01-21T10:11:59.060Z Reads: 72

```
It's a judgement call on your part. If you use the 60A one, the BMS has more authority to protect the cells (it will shut off the output if the current is too high or the voltage is too high or low.) This has an upside and a downside - Upside, the batteries will last longer. Downside, if the vesc does something to the batteries the BMS doesn't like, it'll shut off and you'll suddenly have no power and no brakes (this can be avoided somewhat in the vesc settings).

With the low amp BMS, you'll have to bypass the discharge, so the BMS won't be able to stop the vesc from hurting the cells. But on the flip side you won't have to worry about cutouts.

I like using a BMS with full authority, but a lot of people here don't, because they're larger, and more expensive. 

Either way works, as long as you get your vesc all set up right.
```

## \#3846 Posted by: amazingdave Posted at: 2019-01-21T10:43:47.242Z Reads: 73

```
The no power no brakes scenario could happen at 2 of the worst case moments for a fall If the bms is not rated high enough.  Full acceleration (bms shutoff leads to superman to faceplant). and heavy braking early in your ride ( leads to death by car or braking using body surface as an ablative compound). 

Either use a high rated bms or bypass it for discharge leaving the vesc to deal with low and high voltage cutouts which will be safer for you... the battery will be safe too if you program the vesc with battery health in mind. 

Just my opinion.
```

The problem is after they are under extreme vibration for 500 miles the wires will short out because all their insulation rubbed off and they will start a fire inside the tube, causing neighboring cells to start fires in a chain reaction.

## \#3902 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-01-22T20:20:46.659Z Reads: 76

```
Another reason your bolts were easily stripped (two, actually) is that you are using button head screws, which have a smaller drive than cap head screws of the same size. Also, they appear to be stainless, which is significantly less strong and softer than alloy steel.

 Another thing you can do to prevent stripping if you haven't already, is get a set of Wera HexPlus allen wrenches. Yes, they're expensive, but they work better than anything else.
```

## \#3919 Posted by: Itsmedant Posted at: 2019-01-22T21:13:18.885Z Reads: 69

```
You need to plan your deck out a bit more before you buy anything. How fast are you going to go? What battery size are you planning? How heavy are you? 

All of this goes into how many layers you want. Start with maple, can’t go wrong there. 9-11 plys is a good range. If you are going to do a cut out go higher in plys.

## \#3947 Posted by: hazza Posted at: 2019-01-23T12:57:45.763Z Reads: 69

```
Hi I have a question, why do most bestech bms say that the overvoltage protection voltage is 4.20 - 4.35 volts if 4.35 volts can damage your pack?
I look forward to your response.
```

---
## \#3948 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-23T13:09:51.184Z Reads: 68

```
It's only a failsafe.

4.35V will damage your pack.  The BMS has a failsafe to prevent a fire.  Under normal circumstances it should never get to 4.35V and the BMS will never kick that off.  If for some reason you have a catastrophic malfunction, it will shut it off before a fire happens while charging....
```

## \#3967 Posted by: epster Posted at: 2019-01-23T22:44:25.786Z Reads: 68

```
I also have an question about the relation between amperage of a battery and amperage of the motor. I always see different amperage set and come out off stats posted. How is that. For instance I have a battery pack of 12S1P that can deliver a Amperage of 100A continuous (LIPO`s). I have 2 TB vesc`s  so i max the wattage of the battery at 45A continuous so I wont overload them. I do that because the amperage outputted by the battery goes straight through the VESC thats rated at 50A continuous right? I am not sure at this point hahah :sweat_smile:.

But TB has their 6374 motors rated at 80A continuous. So I can set the motor amperage to 75A continuous to be safe again. I calculate the ERPM beforehand so that it wont exceed 80000ERPM. But how is it possible that the motor can handle and also will receive 75Amps when I only put 45A in? How does that work? Is the amperage inputted somehow transferred into more then 45A by the VESC?
```

---
## \#3968 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-23T22:47:02.952Z Reads: 71

```
[quote="epster, post:3967, topic:9559"]
80000ERPM
[/quote]

is 60,000 erpm

[quote="epster, post:3967, topic:9559"]
But how is it possible that the motor can handle and also will receive 75Amps when I only put 45A in? How does that work? Is the amperage inputted somehow transferred into more then 45A by the VESC?
[/quote]

Yes.  It's a PWM square wave so, for example, if it was ON at 75A for 63 microseconds and OFF for 87μs, then it would be running at a 42% duty cycle and so the "battery amps" would be 31.5A even though the "motor amps" is 75A
```

## \#4044 Posted by: wafflejock Posted at: 2019-01-25T18:30:24.649Z Reads: 71

```
All USB is 5V by standard (talking about everything 2.0 and not USB C/3.0 standard).  The new standard allows for higher voltage but there's "negotiation' that happens with the device so the device basically pulls a line high or low to indicate to the charger to go into high power mode then it's somewhere around 24V I believe (for charging laptops etc.)

With different 5V adapters you'll see the output amperage rating on them varies, if the charge circuit in your device limits the current lower than the adapter can put out then there's no issue.  If the charge circuit doesn't limit the current then it may draw up to however much current the adapter can put out, typically if you draw more than that I believe the adapter will heat up and either switch on and off or dip in power (think this depends on switching power supply or not but details here are where I get lost).

I just bought a little USB power tester that shows how much actual current is flowing from an adapter to a device (because I'm curious about these things).
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01D9Y6ZFW/

With a device like the above it gives you Watts read out so you can divide Wh on the device by Watts being delivered and assuming it's off or not using much power can calculate time to charge pretty accurately.
```

## \#4104 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-01-28T09:44:05.811Z Reads: 74

```
@perpetual-motion many trampa-style builds I've seen have the ESCs  mounted above the rear truck, behind tthe rear foot, which keeps the wires to the motors nice and short - you just have to have two wires from the battery to the ESCs, rather than sixteen (3 phases, power, ground and U, V, W hall outputs per motor) like you'd need if you had the ESCs in the middle.
```

@perpetual-motion
As @venom121212 said, the most easy way is to cut the sensor wires and solder an extension to it.

## \#4107 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-01-29T09:25:09.708Z Reads: 73

```
They're called setscrews or grub screws. I'd guess m6 by about 12mm long. You can get them online, or at most hardware stores. (Don't get the cheap chinese ones, they're made of cheese, rather than steel.)

Don't forget to use threadlocker on all those, you don't want anything coming loose during a ride.

```
So guys I have a choice to make about batteries and charging of them and I would like your help. So here is the situation. I have got a 12S setup with 3x4S lipos rated to charge up to 10A continuous. I currently have a small reaktor 250W charger but I don't have a big power supply just a cheap one. It is 19v at 3A. But because the reaktor only takes ...-18v`s the guys form hobbyking recommended me to charger at 2A, so I won't blow the fuse (I think that was the reason if I remember correctly). 
At this point I am like 95% done with my board and I just want to ride it. A couple of friends of mine live in a village about 10 km away from me, so I always ride there to hang out. But since I am upgrading to dual 6374`s my range will drop with about 60% ish. 
Now I have the choice to upgrade my charging (in 2 variations) or get a new set of batteries, so I can just swap them and get back for sure. 

Upgrading my charger solution 1:
I get a new power supply for my Reaktor, so I will be able to charge my battery at 10A. The thing with this solution is that I will always have to open my enclosure, so I can't screw it down. The other thing is that when I charge them I have to set a voltage I want to charge them to. If the situation occurs that I have to go home quickly no matter the situation I will have one battery low on voltage which will bottleneck the total capacity so it will just discharge from that percentage. That's because I am only allowed to charge at 6S max. Great choice for the 4S afterwards. Didn't know too much about batteries back then :grin:. 
If I go with this solution I have a question. About the power supply I will need. Since the reaktor can charge up to 6S to a total of 250W I will be able to charge the 4S at 10A that I know. But my power supply does that have to supply a wattage of 250W+ and then I am good to go or are there some sort of limitations to watch out for? For instance if the power supply is rated at  6A does that mean I can only charge at 6A? Maybe something else like if the voltage is higher than 22.2 of the power supply it will blow a fuse in the turnigy reaktor? I have no Idea haha Teach me please :slight_smile:.

Upgrading my charger solution 2:
I make a BMS and wire it up for charging. The thing with this is that I will have to buy a new charger for 12S and that that charger will probably rated for 12s at only 5A. I also kind off eliminate the usage of being able to swap out batteries since I will be screwing my enclosure down. That also gives me an advantage because I will be able to make my board look nicer and gets rid of the need to open it up as mentioned earlier.

The 3rd option was to buy new batteries:
This one kind off explains itself. I just get a couple of new batteries, so I will always be able to ride home if needed. 

So what would you guys do if you were in the same situation? Does anyone have experience with these type of situations?
If I got something wrong just tell me I am here to learn haha. :smile:

## \#4113 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-01-29T16:47:05.082Z Reads: 68

```
Solution 2 is way, way, way better than solution 1.  You CANNOT use the battery if the the three packs aren't balanced, you will end up destroying the batteries.

Solution 3 is overkill.  You have batteries.

Also I don't advise making your board such that you must open the enclosure to charge it.
```

## \#4142 Posted by: mmaner Posted at: 2019-01-30T14:26:43.006Z Reads: 77

```
You can spend a couple hours with a a dremel or drill press and make the hanger ends of paris trucks perfectly round and use @psychotiller RIPBA mounts or virtually any caliber mount (just drill it out to make it fit a round hanger).  Using grub screws with pre-drilled slots and loctite, they will never move.  

The benefit?  Paris trucks ride so much better than Caliber 2 trucks, they also last longer and the bushing seat is a hack and slash job like C2's so your bushing last a lot longer.

## \#4175 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-01-31T00:00:18.494Z Reads: 73

```
@ZachTetra You'll probably trip the over current protection in the pwoer supply. You won't damage anything, but it won't behave right.

@pookybear the third pin is switched when you insert the plug. Leave it unconnected unless you need it for something. 

@paulbriz experiment to find the best spot welding settings. You want a weld that is so strong that it'll leave a little piece of the strip behind when you try to remove it. 
For dewelding, peel off the strips and then use a Dremel or something to smooth out the battery terminals again.
Don't use anything plastic for insulation under the nickel, use fish paper because it's heat and abrasion resistant. 

@yelnats8j powder coat looks great and is very tough, but it adds thickness more than paint or anodizing (anodizing adds none at all), so if you have any critical dimensions, it can mess with them.
```

```
Hey everyone! I have a question regarding different motor options. Specifically, I am confused as to the difference between the Maytech sealed 6355 motor, and Maytech sealed 6374 motor.

Both motors are available in 170kv and 190kv options, both are sensored. Both support 2-12s voltages (so I'm assuming max around 50.4V), and both support a max current of 65A. If we dismiss the 1 entry on aliexpress that states that the 6355 motor has a max wattage of 2000, and 2800 (on the same page, I know :man_facepalming: ), then the correct wattages appear to be 3510W for the 6355, and 3550W for the 6374. The difference in price between the 2 motors appears to be around $20.

So, my question!

Besides heat dissipation, is there any reason to pick the heavier and more expensive 6374 motor? If the max current and voltage limits and kv are the same, then both of these motors should produce the same amount of torque and max speed, right? (Especially since 50.4V * 65A = 3276W, less than stated in the motor's descriptions!) Or is the bigger motor bound to be more energy efficient?

Also, since I'm planning a single motor drive for my younger brother on just 10S, do I even need to worry about heat? I'd love to hear your thoughts!

Sidenote: I do see a lot of listings saying that max current for the 6355 is 50A, and rated for 55A. Could the listings stating 65A for the 6355 just be erroneous? Or are there just a lot of different models / options? :smiley:
```

## \#4201 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2019-02-01T05:21:22.522Z Reads: 77

```
[quote="rusins, post:4198, topic:9559"]
Besides heat dissipation, is there any reason to pick the heavier and more expensive 6374 motor? If the max current and voltage limits and kv are the same, then both of these motors should produce the same amount of torque and max speed, right? (Especially since 50.4V * 65A = 3276W, less than stated in the motor’s descriptions!) Or is the bigger motor bound to be more energy efficient?

Also, since I’m planning a single motor drive for my younger brother on just 10S, do I even need to worry about heat? I’d love to hear your thoughts!
[/quote]

Two trains of thought.  1.  Your brother I'm assuming is light so weight is not an issue so realistically speaking a single drive 6355 will get him about just fine and when he eventually gets heavier he can add another motor as and when he needs it.
2.  6374 single drive will do him fine now and even when hes heavier if you don't live in San Francisco or an equivalent hilly area.

[quote="rusins, post:4198, topic:9559"]
Sidenote: I do see a lot of listings saying that max current for the 6355 is 50A, and rated for 55A. Could the listings stating 65A for the 6355 just be erroneous? Or are there just a lot of different models / options?
[/quote]
Take what motor manufacturers state with a grain of salt to be honest.They err on the side of caution.  Its best to use the specs as a guide not gospel.  Do your own testing and see what works.  Its all about the heat.   A 6374 will run the same motor amps as a 6355 but will not get as hot which in reality means it will last longer.  I guarantee that you can run the 74 version of the maytech motor at a higher motor max than the 55 with the same temp readings.
As @briman05 says its probably best to set him up with the 6374 now as if hes anything like my youngest son he will eventually want a fire breathing dragon with twin big cans.
```

## \#4240 Posted by: mmaner Posted at: 2019-02-03T23:00:02.029Z Reads: 69

```
If it doesn't have one, make a flat spot in the motor shaft where 1 of the grub screws hits and use blue loctite, just a couple of drops on opposite sides of the shaft and on the grub screws. 

Do this and it's much easier to remove the pulley for maintenance and replacement. I don't use keyways because they make noise and they aren't necessary if you do what I suggest above.
```

## \#4320 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-02-07T02:12:25.206Z Reads: 72

```
Based on some quick and dirty calculation (I ran the numbers in an e-bike calculator), assuming you can match the rolling/wind resistance of a recumbent bike, it'll be just barely able to hit 60km/h on level ground on full throttle. Take this with a pound of salt, I could have made a mistake and the numbers I got might be off significantly. But just an educated wild-ass guess, it'll be a little underpowered and you'd be better off using a different motor. 

Keep in mind that as long as you get your gear ratio correct, watts matter more than torque at the motor. 1000rpm and 9nm of torque is not better than 6000rpm and 5nm of torque. (960 watts, vs 3000.)
```

## \#4335 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-02-08T05:54:32.768Z Reads: 73

```
I've never modified for ABEC-style cores, but I have a tip from modifying ABEC pulleys to fit kegel style cores --

I intentionally put the bolts 1 degree too far on each side, so they really grip the core tight.  So half the bolts are 1 degree too far forward on the rotation, and the other half are 1 degree too far rearward on the rotation.  Really makes it so there is no slippage at all.

## \#4351 Posted by: Andy87 Posted at: 2019-02-09T11:23:32.179Z Reads: 75

```
If you use the I max b6 Charger you will need about 3.5h to charge one 6s pack without balancing time. It’s not an issue, but some people get confused with the charger rating.
It’s not a 5A charger, it’s a 60w charger.
You need to take your nominal voltage which would be 22,2V and devide the Watts through it.
60w / 22,2v =  2,7A Maximum
```

## \#4391 Posted by: ZachTetra Posted at: 2019-02-10T04:53:49.809Z Reads: 71

## \#4392 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-02-10T06:09:55.367Z Reads: 72

```
I wouldn't recommend either of those. Both hot glue and double sided tape have thermal limits, and hot glue also gets weak and brittle in the cold. I'd recommend screws if possible, or epoxy (both surfaces sanded rough), or maybe a urethane construction adhesive like liquid nails, as long as you've tested it for strength and compatibility with the materials it's sticking to. You want the absolute strongest attachment you can get, with some flex.

Imagine taking the completed board and slamming it on the floor as hard as you can for an hour straight. That's the kind of abuse an esk8 takes from vibration, so construct accordingly.
```

## \#4403 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2019-02-11T00:51:47.319Z Reads: 73

```
You need to get it out of there.  Use a sharp drill bit that is smaller than the outside threaded section but big enough to remove the inside core.  Once you have drilled it then use a small flat bladed screwdriver to wedge out the outside threaded section from the deck.  If you get it right the wall of the insert will be thin enough to break away from the deck and leave the outside thread cut into the deck intact.  If you get it wrong you will have to up the size of the new insert.
```

## \#4407 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-02-11T01:28:26.434Z Reads: 73

```
If it's the internal thread that's stripped, you can repair it using a heli-coil kit. Basically you drill out the old thread with a specific size drill, tap it with a special tap, and then insert a special spring that forms new threads that are stronger than the original.

This will only work if there's a good amount of extra material left for the heli-coil to hold on to, if it's too thin after being drilled and tapped, the brass will just break.
```

## \#4431 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-02-11T23:25:32.628Z Reads: 69

```
If you want waterproof and protection, there are ways to do that, but WD-40 is not the way

MG Chemicals Acrylic Conformal Coating (in the 55ml brush-on bottle) on any heatsinks and motor sensor boards and windings
and
MG Chemicals Modified Silicone Conformal Coating (in the 55ml brush-on bottle) on everything else, like the circuit boards and stuff

That will make it waterproof.  (which is different from water-resistant)
```

Same with motor pulley. Below 13th the contact of the belt is just too less.

## \#4632 Posted by: Flashgod224 Posted at: 2019-02-17T00:05:34.793Z Reads: 65

```
You just need to make sure you are connecting the balance leads appropriately. for ex if there was 12 leads only (meaning no negative balance wire), the wires should go in series of voltage from B1 to B12. Always be safe and check with a Voltage meter. If there was a BMS layout it would have been easier lol

Edit: I busted a BMS because I had the leads the other way around and the BMS was trying to regulate the voltage backwards. It got so hot and just didn't allow me to charge anymore. Good thing cheap BMS's are easy to replace and do not much harm (If monitored that is).

## \#4744 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-02-22T08:12:32.169Z Reads: 83

```
DC5521 sockets have three pins: pin, jacket, and switched. The switched one is shorted to jacket, **until** you plug it in. Figure out which one is which using a multimeter (If you don't have a multimeter, slap yourself and get one), and don't use the switched one.
```

What is different for ESC's between hub motors and normally outrunners ?

## \#4817 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-02-25T04:48:15.187Z Reads: 80

```
That's the case. The ERPM limit might be different, but the main difference is that outrunner motors are MUCH more powerful than hubs, and the prebuilt ESCs are rated for that low power, so they won't be able to run a more powerful outrunner.
```

## \#4859 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-02-28T22:59:46.464Z Reads: 78

```
Dual 6374 is like an extreme performance musclecar and are really heavy.

Dual 8080 are *excessive extra weight*

Dual 6374 are *overkill / high performance*

Dual 6355 are *great*

Dual 5065 are *good*

Single 6384 is *good*

Single 6374 is *good*

Single 6355 is *adequate*

Single 5065 is *not adequate*
```

## \#4861 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-02-28T23:25:50.771Z Reads: 78

```
It depends how many cells you use. Li-ion cylindrical cells have a lower power/weight ratio compared to LiPo, but they hold WAY more energy. So you'll need a larger pack to equal the discharge performance of a lipo pack, but you'll also get a far greater range out of the bargain as well.
```
