## \#4864 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-03-01T01:11:58.354Z Reads: 83

```
@porb @ZachTetra A 6355 is 60ish **motor amps**, which doesn't translate to battery amps in a 1:1 ratio. You can run fewer battery amps and the vesc will step down the battery voltage, and step up the motor amps. I'd say a minimum of 30 battery amps per motor is acceptable, 40+ is good. 

The only time you'll really notice the difference is with hard acceleration at speed - It won't affect your top speed, or the initial launch from a standing start. The lower your battery amps, the sooner your acceleration will drop off - Either way, if you punch it from a standstill, the motor will see 60 amps, but it'll drop off faster if you have fewer battery amps. You'll hit the same top speed (Within reason) but it'll take longer with less battery amps.
```

## \#4881 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-03-04T04:21:46.520Z Reads: 85

```
Check your pack when you first assemble it into your board, both at full charge and at partial to make sure  all your P groups are balanced. 

Check it again every time you do maintenance on your board, such as changing belts, wheels, cleaning/lubing/inspecting/replacing bearings, etc.

Don't treat your equipment as a black box, and be proactive in checking for signs of distress before you have a more catastrophic failure.

Since you don't have a BMS that can stop you from damaging your pack, the burden is on you to keep an eye on it. That's the disadvantage of running bypassed - you have to pay more attention.
```

## \#4914 Posted by: rusins Posted at: 2019-03-04T23:05:06.701Z Reads: 85

```
[quote="atlasdev, post:4912, topic:9559"]
Max battery amps = Cell max * Cells in serie = 15 * 12 = 180A
[/quote]

Nope! Max battery amps are amps per cell * cells in parallel. Putting cells in series increases voltage, which lets your motor spin faster = higher top speed.

Also, at low speeds your ESC will convert the high voltage of your battery to lower voltage, and because the watts will be the same (ignoring small losses), at those low voltages you can still get a lot of motor current. Only thing impacting your startup acceleration will be the size of your motors. Max battery amps will determine how long / till what speed you can maintain that current for the acceleration.

P.S. It's perfectly fine for the battery to be the bottleneck of the theoretical limits of the system. :smiley:
```

## \#4941 Posted by: rusins Posted at: 2019-03-06T02:32:27.856Z Reads: 86

```
To measure voltage of the packs in series, you connect them in series.

Multimeter negative probe goes to battery no. 1 –
Battery no. 1 + connects to battery no. 2 –
battery no. 2 + connects to the multimeter's positive probe.

Imho, you might want to learn a few basic things about electrical circuits before you do this kind of stuff, or, ask someone for help and follow their diagrams very closely :smiley:

As for B0 and B1 – those do sound like pins of balance wires, and B0 is usually same voltage as the battery's negative terminal. (Depends on amount of balance wires VS cell count in the Lipo.) I'm not sure exactly what you're asking, but pictures would help :slight_smile:

Edit: Seems like @b264 is already helping you in another thread. Cool. :+1:
```

## \#4946 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-03-06T10:23:05.109Z Reads: 83

```
The balance wires on lipo batteries always have N+1 wires, with N being the number of cells. For a 6s lipo, that means you have 7 wires - One that goes to negative, (same as the big black wire), one that goes to positive (same as the big red wire) and one between each cell. 

Since you have the positive of the first pack connected to the negative of the second pack, then the last pin of pack1 and the first pin of pack2 are also connected together. This is fine, when you are making up your BMS balance pigtail, just use only one of these wires and ignore the other, then keep counting like normal. It makes zero difference which of the two you use or ignore. You will have a total of 13 wires: one negative, one positive, and one in between each cell. On your specific BMS, the first wire (0v, negative) is not used since it's the same as B-. This leaves the remaining twelve wires (from 3.7 to 44.4 measuring from ground) to go to pins 1 through 12 on your BMS.
```

## \#5007 Posted by: Dirt_Bag Posted at: 2019-03-09T07:06:00.303Z Reads: 82

```
None, but for motor shafts without one, you can make a small notch and put the set screw into it. If you have a motor with a keyway, you can put the set screw into it as well ofc. In high torque applications i recommend threading 1 more 3mm hole into the pulley right above or below on the existing holes. This way you have 2 screws going into 1 keyway. ```

## \#5022 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-03-09T23:42:33.181Z Reads: 80

```
Look in the "Maximum amps for chassis wiring" column and remember that's continuous and for slightly longer runs of wire than we use in a tiny esk8, so we can exceed that by a bit, but I wouldn't go too far over that.  I personally don't exceed those numbers at all on the battery side and exceed them no more than 100% on the motor phase wire side

It's counter-intuitive, but the highest temp iron is how you keep the cells the coolest

Obligatory: **soldering on lithium cells is *not recommended***

(there is a reason I end every post with that)
```

## \#5061 Posted by: s5300 Posted at: 2019-03-11T02:49:46.171Z Reads: 76

```
Making your own is somewhat simple imo.

Scrap a microwave. Shouldn't be hard to find one on Craigslist or something. Take the transformer. Do not touch the magnetron. Youtube is an easy way to see how to safely do this procedure.

Get some quality 4AWG (6 or 8 would also probably work) welding wire. Electron Beam Technology in the USA has AMAZING deals monthly.

Buy the Arduino kit to go with the microwave transformer. Then stealthily borrow your parents or neighbors car battery.

Buy some copper butt connectors shove them in the welding wire, properly connect them after tapping a hole for a set screw, insert probes, and ya got yerself a Gucci spot-welder.

I realize this kinda sounds like bullshit for the noob thread... But it's all actually pretty easy and all on YouTube quite a few times. Honestly, the most expensive part of you don't have an easy way to get it around you will be the electrode holder option.
```

## \#5101 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-03-14T04:36:36.930Z Reads: 76

```
Two things: First, you can't use a 10s BMS for a 9s battery unless is **specifically** says it can do multiple different cell numbers (Hint- most cheap ones can't.) 

Second, you would remove the fourth wire on the first two sets of balance leads - That is, if you have ground, 1-2, 2-3 and positive on each pack, then your arrangement should be ground, 1-2, 2-3, then ground from pack 2, then 1-2 from pack 2, 2-3 from pack 2, then ground from pack 3, and so on, ending with the positive from pack 3, for a total of 10 wires.

second question: Yes, but. You can still use regen braking, but just set your current limits at safe and sane levels (max regen of -12A or so) and don't try to go down a long or steep hill when your cells are at or near 100%.
```

---
## \#5102 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-03-14T04:43:30.385Z Reads: 77

```
So, do both batteries show the same reading on each device? As in, If you plug pack 1 into the charger and get 26%, and then plug pack 2 into the charger, is it also 26%?

If the answer is yes they are the same, then the difference is your charger and meter have different settings for the cutoff voltage used to calculate state of charge. The meter is probably calibrated for li-ion, in which "empty" is at between 2.5 and 3 volts, whereas your charger is calibrated for li-po, where the "empty" voltage is more like 3.7 or 3.5. This leads to a shifting of the apparent state of charge.

I'd recommend not running those cells down below ~30% on the battery meter, since that would be getting close to ~3.7v. (You can experiment and figure out exactly what percentage on the meter corresponds with 0% on the charger if you want.)
```

## \#5134 Posted by: taz Posted at: 2019-03-15T03:01:17.432Z Reads: 78

Thank you for your reply!

> The motor price is in Euro never mention $ :wink:

I would rather have a 12s3p, but the board does not really allow for it, see the following image:

![](https://i.imgur.com/rMt6p6H.jpg)

It has two big pockets where everything would have to fit in. It barely fits a glued 5p pack in the width (I'm looking into not using cell holders so I can make it a 10s5p). If you build a 10s battery you'll have 5 packs in both pockets, with 2x +/- 15cm left for your VESC, BMS, receiver and other stuff. ## \#5236 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-03-20T20:07:31.787Z Reads: 84

```
[quote="3_2016, post:5233, topic:9559"]
When it comes to adjusting throttle curve for brakes is it the negative number (ex.: -12) that creates less aggressive braking or is it the positive number?
[/quote]

Motor Max: max torque at low speed  
Motor Min: max brake at low speed  
Battery Max: max torque at high speed  
Battery Min: max brake at high speed  

Both "Min" should be negative
```

## \#5263 Posted by: trampa Posted at: 2019-03-21T07:33:07.364Z Reads: 87

```
VESC 6 Plus would be the choice if you want a reliable three shunt VESC.
The SIX Plus has three phase shunts and has self adjusting filters for accurate voltage and current readings, which are important to do the real time FOC calculations, driving the motor.
This means it delivers the power ultra smooth and linear to the throttle input.
ESC like the Focbox, VESC 4 based HW, Unity etc. feature a power stage similar to the VESC 4 Those ESCs measure the currents on two phases only and on the battery side, not the motor side.
This means that the currents can't be measured precisely enough for seamless FOC operation. In between 60 and 100% power, the ESC will respond non linear to the throttle input. In between 80 and 100% duty cycle, the power can jump from one level to another. Especially on high power off-road builds this is very noticeable.  MTBs can be very energy hungry and drawing a lot of Amps happens quite often. So the ESC and all connections should be capable and overrated. 

Why you want a three shunt ESC:
https://vesc-project.com/node/403
```

## \#5333 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-03-22T22:08:34.720Z Reads: 65

```
[quote="Superflim, post:5330, topic:9559, full:true"]
Does a Dual setup deliver more power/acceleration than single setup when the same amount of watts is delivered?
[/quote]

Delivered from where?

When the same amount of watts is delivered from the **battery**, single drive has less friction and losses, and thus, more torque.

When the same amount of watts is delivered from the **wheels**, dual drive has more traction, and thus, more torque.
```

## \#5338 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-03-23T21:45:08.067Z Reads: 78

```
Changing your battery setup from 12s5p to 10s6p (just picking ones with easy numbers) won't give you any extra range in and of itself because there are the same number of cells overall, and thus the same number of watt-hours. 

Going slower will increase your range, because aerodynamic drag increases with the square of your speed. This means you'll use four times as much power going 40MPH than you would going 20MPH (In an ideal world without other factors).

You could always just adjust your gearing to lower your top speed as well.
```

## \#5358 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-03-25T09:24:44.904Z Reads: 83

```
@Bas1 I dunno about motor beta, but the cutoff settings are thus:

Cutoff start is when the controller starts to reduce power going to your motors. This is when the battery is almost dead.

Cutoff end is when the controller essentially stops delivering power to the motors completely. This is when your battery is all the way dead.

Doing it this way means the controller won't just stop abruptly when your battery gets low. Instead it'll gradually reduce power from the start voltage to the end voltage so you can limp home to recharge.
```

## \#5382 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-03-26T05:00:57.358Z Reads: 78

```
There are two ways shrink wrap is measured: Diameter, if it's sold as round tube, and width, if it's sold creased flat. For the same piece of tubing 100mm in diameter, if it's measured flat, it'll be 157mm.

Measure the circumference of your pack where the shrink will go, and then calculate the diameter needed to go around it and add ~20%. If you need the flat dimension instead of diameter, then multiply the number you got by 1.57.
```

## \#5388 Posted by: venom121212 Posted at: 2019-03-26T15:06:01.411Z Reads: 80

```
Charge port fuse is NECESSARY to help prevent your pack from bursting into flames in the event of a charger malfunction. It can be built in to the battery but yes, it goes between charge port and BMS (typically on negative line)

The fuse between BMS and battery comes to cell level fusing which not many packs are doing at the moment. 

The fuse between battery pack and electronic speed controller (esc) is a bit different. This is an optional one and comes down to whether you trust your speed controller to be able to handle a voltage spike for a few seconds or not. Personally, I run un-fused in this regard because I trust my Unity esc to handle a larger power draw if I need it. I would rather not be thrown off my board at full speed and/or lose control when a fuse blows at the sacrifice of MAYBE one day blowing my esc.
```

## \#5400 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-03-28T03:16:56.639Z Reads: 85

```
First of all, the "C" numbers given by lipo manufacturers are, for lack of better words, complete bullshit.  So, you're reduced to guessing.

As far as Samsung 18650-30Q cells, they are rated at 15A continuous and it's widely known they are underrated and can do 20A continuous.  So you'd need at least 8P to get 160A.  If you want 50.4V then it'd have to be a 12S8P at a minimum which is huge and and heavy, using 96 cells.

If you need that much current you might need lipo or LiFePO4 depending on your other needs.

Pinging all you experienced battery builders: @barajabali @longhairedboy @psychotiller @hyperIon1 @hyperIon2     

I've heard nickel to nickel welds are tough. 

I was planning originally on layering 5 - 6 layers of nickel for a 175A total capable set of cells in 10S.

I did some test nickel to nickel welds... And they aren't nearly as strong as the welds to cells themselves. The nickel to cells leave a nice tiny hole on each spot weld when yanked off. 

The nickel to nickel welds, at full power, are strong-ish, but once I get it started I can basically peel it off as if it's medium strength Velcro, maybe less... And no holes or metal tearing when split apart. Is this just par for the course when it comes to nickel?

Should I just make sure it's on better by welding more spots on the nickel to to nickel sections (all only P-group connections)?

Or should I try maybe only one or two 0.15mm nickel strips and a soldered solid core copper wire across the P group with an 80-100W iron, pre-tinned nickel strip [may even pre-tin prior to spot welding it..?] and copper wire, and cooled with cool damp sponge in order to make the P group connections robust enough to deliver 75+A across a couple cells worth of what would have been layers of nickel?

## \#5439 Posted by: hyperIon1 Posted at: 2019-03-29T00:58:16.318Z Reads: 78

```
[quote="skatardude10, post:5438, topic:9559"]
I did some test nickel to nickel welds… And they aren’t nearly as strong as the welds to cells themselves. The nickel to cells leave a nice tiny hole on each spot weld when yanked off.
[/quote]

Yes, you are correct any more than 3 layers and the welds don't hold well. Finding the sweet spot depends on what your demands are, and of course, there is not just one right way, in fact, several have emerged on the forum depending on your specific scenario. flat braided copper wire has been used if flex is needed and even solid copper bars, technics, and material quality play a hand.  You also have to keep in mind to much of a good thing is just that, too much. More material higher resistance, higher resistance more heat, and lost power.
```

## \#5513 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-04-02T21:17:25.565Z Reads: 75

```
The anti-spark blowing typically won't blow up your BMS.  Also whether you're discharging through the BMS or bypassing it (using it for charge-only) is a drastic difference. ## \#5522 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-02T22:33:31.893Z Reads: 81

```
@ryansinatra That screw actually doesn't look completely rounded out. I'd recommend getting a T20 torx bit (They're like $1 at most big-box stores) and gently hammer it into the screw. (It might even fit without hammering.) Then use a 1/4" driver of some sort on the torx bit.

After you've got it out, I'd recommend either
A: If you stay with stainless hardware, stay with torx screws, and use a torx driver. You'll twist the head off the screw before you strip it.
or
B: If you plan to use hex, go with high strength (grade 12.9) alloy steel screws rather than stainless, and use Wera hex-plus wrenches. They're the best ones out there, and are absolutely worth the money.
```

## \#5536 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-03T06:37:28.769Z Reads: 85

```
Since it's over 300WH, I think you're kind of stuck. According to UPS and the other shipping providers I checked, 

"Shipping of lithium ion cells >60 WH and batteries >300 WH and lithium metal cells >5 grams
lithium per cell and >25 grams per battery as fully regulated Class 9 hazardous materials.

• This includes Class 9 batteries that are “packed with” and “contained in” equipment. There is no
general relief for larger batteries.

• There is a Class 9 Miscellaneous label that was developed specifically for lithium battery shipments."

You need a [hazardous materials shipping contract.](https://www.ups.com/assets/resources/media/hazmat_contract.pdf)
```

---
## \#5537 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-03T08:01:17.083Z Reads: 81

```
Many people ship large batteries labeled as being below the 300WH limit and get away with it, but you always run the risk of it being confiscated, or you being fined for shipping mislabeled hazardous goods.

I've seen several builders on here make "shipping friendly" multi-part battery packs, with each part being within the shipping regulations and classified as an individual battery. In your case, splitting it in half would do the trick, but it'd be a pain to do that to an already-complete pack safely and cleanly.
```

## \#5546 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-04T05:03:54.188Z Reads: 83

```
The positive does need to be connected. Positive to the positive terminal of the cell you're measuring, negative to the negative. Or, alternatively, you can put the negative on the pack negative, and put the positive on each wire in succession afterwards and measure the increase. 

One of the main issues with building a "simple" battery monitoring doohickey with app support is the relatively high voltages it has to deal with, as well as quiescent current drain. You don't want your battery monitor to drain your battery, and you especially don't want it to drain it unevenly. Thus, you either have to have a very low quiescent current, or have a way to completely turn it off when not in use. The combination of high voltage and low quiescent current is a tough one, especially on a (preferably) small, simple, compact and cheap device.

Also, define "too expensive" regarding a smart BMS.
```

## \#5585 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-05T21:52:50.753Z Reads: 72

```
You can't have unequal parallel strings. If you have three batteries in series and one in parallel with them, then the three batteries would just dump charge into the one until it explodes. If you want to keep your 12s setup and go from 1p to 2p, then you need a total of **six** packs. Three in series, plus another three in series next to the first three.

If you only have four batteries, the best you can do is 8s2p, which would be two in series, with two more in series next to the first two.

Keep in mind that going from a 12s1p to an 8s2p will only get you a 33% increase in range, and it will cost you 33% of your top speed as well. 

If you want double your range, you need double the batteries.
```

## \#5588 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-05T22:07:03.297Z Reads: 70

```
I'd be worried about two things: First, if the balance wires are loose, then the BMS can't balance those cells, which is bad. Second, if the BMS has zero voltage reading from some cells, it may just decide to shut down and you could streetface when your board quits mid-ride.

You should fix it ASAP.
```

## \#5590 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-05T22:30:55.265Z Reads: 63

```
If you insist on using your board while the BMS is questionable, I'd recommend doing a complete balance check of all cells, making sure they're within 0.05v of eachother (And manually balancing them if not), and then completely disconnecting/bypassing the BMS, including discharge leads temporarily to remove any chance of streetface.
```

## \#5630 Posted by: JCV Posted at: 2019-04-06T22:22:01.117Z Reads: 79

```
Ok so what are the pros and cons of either using a chain drive or belt drive?
```

---
## \#5631 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-06T23:23:55.601Z Reads: 78

```
Belt drive is super common and well-tested in esk8, so parts specifically designed for esk8 are more available than chain. Belts are also quieter, and don't require any lubrication. Belts have smaller teeth than chain, so the pulleys can be smaller, and have a larger range of incremental sizes.

Chains can transmit more power, but unless you're pushing 5+ KW, I don't think that should factor into the choice. Chains are narrower, so if you're really hurting for a few extra mm of space, that can be a reason. Chains can be more resistant to fouling by snow or other material, which can get packed into a belt drive and break the belt.

Overall unless you have a specific reason to pick chain, I'd go with belt.
```

## \#5636 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-07T20:36:34.465Z Reads: 77

```
That is my understanding, yes. Your mileage may vary, but based on all the info I've seen, changing the battery max (within reason) doesn't affect motor torque at low speed. For low battery current settings (10, 20, etc), the "low speed" regime that the battery current doesn't affect may be very small. It depends on a myriad of factors, including your battery voltage, motor KV, motor impedance/resistance, gearing, etc.
```

## \#5637 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-07T20:50:45.956Z Reads: 80

```
Take a look at [this graph](https://www.ebikes.ca/tools/simulator.html?bopen=true&cont=cust_20_40_0.03_V&cont_b=cust_40_40_0.03_V&motor_b=MGRIN2705_SA&motor=MGRIN2705_SA&batt=B7223_AC&batt_b=B7223_AC&axis=mph). It's for ebikes rather than esk8, but the concepts are the same. You'll notice that the peak motor currents are the same, but the graph with the lower battery current begins to tail off before the other. Depending on the motor, controller and battery, the flat part of the blue graph may be very short, or very long.
```

## \#5666 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-04-08T17:56:53.967Z Reads: 77

```
If you aren't putting the whole charging current through it, 26AWG won't melt, assuming you're certain the charge current isn't going through it. (only the balance current which is typically <200mA) However, also remember that thinner wire is more prone to physically breaking after many thousands of miles/kilometers of extreme vibration.

I would use 22AWG or 20AWG -- and 24AWG at a minimum.

26AWG - 2.2A max continuous  
24AWG - 3.5A max continuous  
22AWG - 7A max continuous  
20AWG - 11A max continuous
```

## \#5673 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-08T21:24:21.236Z Reads: 73

```
It can increase amps, but not watts. Most builds, especially duals, run considerably less battery current than motor current. At low RPM (and thus low PWM), the ESC can act as a buck converter, converting the (for example) 40V and 40A from the battery to 20V and 80A for the motor. 

It doesn't really matter if the motor power rating is greater than that of your battery or ESC, because the motor is a dumb lump of copper, iron and neodymium, governed by the simple laws of thermodynamics.
It'd be very bad to try to draw 4KW from a battery that can only safely deliver 2, but running a motor at less than its rated maximum just gives you more safety margin, and can actually improve the efficiency a little.
```

```
Think of it this way:

Spinning your wheel by hand takes very little effort

Spinning the wheel by hand with brakes on takes more effort

That effort directly relates to energy which directly relates to electrical energy able to be recovered. 

If you notice, a hub motor has much more rolling resistance than a free wheel. That is energy exchanged by making the motor work as a generator.

## \#5720 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-09T18:19:04.373Z Reads: 80

```
Freewheeling regenerates practically zero energy. Braking regenerates energy proportional to your speed and the strength of your brakes. 

All motor setups have more resistance than a normal wheel, because the drivetrain has losses, and the motor has losses. If you just went down a mountain without braking, the drivetrain and motor would be warm or hot at the bottom, but your battery wouldn't be any more full, because 100% of the energy was lost as heat. If you applied brakes, the drivetrain would still be warm or hot, but your battery would be fuller, because some of the energy was being captured as electricity.
```

## \#5721 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-09T18:23:45.944Z Reads: 80

```
Looks like a BMS to me. That group of small components on top in the first picture looks like the usual chain of transistors and resistors used to bleed down any cell that's out of balance, and the aluminum plate on the bottom looks like a heat spreader for some fets.

You should look up some info on that BMS to find out how much discharge current it can provide. If it's not enough, you can bypass it for discharge by connecting the "P-" and "B-" pads together with a similarly sized piece of wire.
```

## \#5757 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-11T07:13:55.396Z Reads: 79

```
Like @Andy87 said, spend the extra couple dollars, and go with 10AWG and XT90 connectors, it's cheap insurance. Overkill is underrated, and improves reliability. 30Q cells have a datasheet rating of 15A, but if you compare their discharge graphs to other cells, they actually perform better than many 20A rated cells. Besides, esk8 very rarely provides enough load to draw the full 80A from a pack for more than a dozen seconds or so at a time anyway.

## \#5778 Posted by: ZachTetra Posted at: 2019-04-11T20:48:50.227Z Reads: 73

The charger voltage absolutely has to match the battery voltage (12s to 12s) but the amps is subjective, check the data sheet for your cells to make sure but 4A on a 6p is almost guaranteed to be safe, if its a 30Q then you could charge at 36A theoretically. ## \#5783 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-11T21:09:39.234Z Reads: 70

```
[quote="ZachTetra, post:5776, topic:9559, full:true"]
What’s an indicator of pack drift without a smart BMS or measuring cells individually?
[/quote]

One indicator is that the pack catches on fire, or the cells vent/start to bulge. 
Another is that some cells get hotter than others, or that the pack starts to act sluggish and not deliver enough power, or not keep a full voltage when it's removed from the charger.

All the above signs only show themselves once the pack has already been badly unbalanced and damaged by misuse. Without voltage measurements or a BMS, there's no way to tell until it's too late.
```

## \#5792 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-11T22:48:29.933Z Reads: 71

```
For the battery itself, or the the whole board?
For 10s4p, I wouldn't use any XT60, only an XT90. 
You'll need one female end for the battery, one male end for the board, another male/female pair for the loopkey, and then a pair for each vesc.

I'd just buy like a 5 or 10-pack, they're cheap enough that it makes no sense to not get a couple spares.

Make sure to get at least one XT90-S (antispark version) to use for the loopkey. The rest can be the regular non-antispark.
```

## \#5828 Posted by: wafflejock Posted at: 2019-04-12T14:00:02.750Z Reads: 78

```
Higher C rating is always better it means less internal resistance in all cells and less heat build up/loss/voltage drop under load.  More overhead is always better assuming the mfg isn't just labelling a thing with higher specs than it can actually withstand.  In general the battery will wear less if you aren't pushing it to it's limits during charge or discharge (general rule of thumb having more overhead is always a good thing not running things to their limit either maximums or minimums is good)
```

## \#5913 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-04-14T20:59:23.236Z Reads: 70

```
MG Chemicals only sells wholesale.  You have to find them on eBay or Amazon.

The "silicone" is the most useful, "acrylic" is the second-most useful and "urethane" is useful for large wires and loop keys and stuff.  The solvent in the "acrylic" one is very nasty and eats a lot of things but it's fine on circuit boards.  If you get one, get silicone.  If you get two, get silicone and acrylic.  If you get all three, they are all useful if you know how to use them.

Acrylic is good in a single coat on things that get hot like heatsinks and FETs.  Acrylic also is very runny and is good for seeping into places you can't get the brush.  Acrylic has a nasty solvent.  In a pinch, you could use your wife's clear nail polish and dilute it with a tiny bit of nail polish remover to make a fake version of this.

Silicone is good on PCBs and most things but can hold heat.  It's great in multiple coats.  It's my goto unless there's a reason to use acrylic or urethane.  Use it, and use a lot of it.  One coat, wait, one more coat, wait, one more coat.  Put it wherever you don't want water to be.  It's not going to hurt the electronics, but the water will.  Displace it with this stuff.

Urethane is good on large tactile things like the loop part of a loopkey and the solder junction between two 10AWG wires, et cetera.  It's the least-useful of the three, but still is useful.  It can pop off if flexed too much.
```

## \#5930 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-04-14T22:02:07.159Z Reads: 70

```
[quote="venom121212, post:5928, topic:9559"]
Don’t you technically use a male XT90 attached to your female XT90s?
[/quote]

Yes.

Very rarely I use female XT90.  I use female XT90S and male XT90 and male/female XT60 a lot.

Typically XT60 for a single-motor-in-a-dual-motor system

and XT90 for a single motor system or for both-motors-in-a-dual-motor-system

Like this, where both drive currents go through an XT90 but each ESC itself uses an XT60.

![20190412_223213|690x388](upload://36MfqRAL2RBXpzLk6me5v7iC2k0.jpeg) 

Also, spend the extra few cents and buy "Amass" brand connectors.  It's silly not to.  They're barely more expensive and twice as good.

Keep them plugged together while soldering so the pins stay straight.  That means you'll need a few extra connectors ;-)
```

You will **also** want one of these: 

https://www.amazon.com/XT90-S-Female-Connector-Battery-Charge/dp/B00RVM8U5W 

That is one pair of XT90-S connectors - one female antispark, and one male regular.

You will have a grand total of **six** male connectors, **five** regular female connectors, and **one** female antispark connector to make your loopkey from.

You only need **four** male connectors, **three** regular female connectors, and **one** antispark connector, but it's usually cheaper and/or easier to just get a five-pack so you have spares.
```

## \#5941 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-04-15T05:06:16.040Z Reads: 69

```
Those are the exact same link for both; the same item.

In general, anywhere you can use an XT90 female plug, you can also use an XT90S female plug, but not the other way around.  The male plugs are identical for both.

So, generally you can skip XT90 and only order XT90S.

I have a few XT90 female plugs, and only use them in certain cases.  They do have a slightly bigger contact patch and technically work slightly better (albeit without the antispark resistor).  But we're splitting hairs here.  They're basically the same.
```

## \#5950 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-15T08:49:54.413Z Reads: 71

```
@Yarden 
Yes, but. 

Yes, you can use hub motors as belt motors in theory.
But, you'll essentially have to have access to a machine shop to make it work.
You'd have to make your own custom motor mounts, and your own custom pulley system.
And even then, with many hours and many dollars invested, they still won't be nearly as good as actual motors designed for belt use.

Just buy regular motors if you want belt drive. Save the hubs for a toy board.
```

## \#6056 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-19T07:52:39.311Z Reads: 70

```
At partial duty cycle, the ESC acts like a buck converter - it steps down the battery voltage, and increases the current. As a result, at low speed you can have far more current flowing through the motor than the battery is supplying. Vedder actually uses this method in his synthetic stress tests - Run the motor at extremely low speed, and you can run 80+ motor amps from a 5-amp lab power supply.
```

```

Wow, thanks.  So does that mean that the main output the VESC's are advertising i.e. "Flipsky 50a VESC 4.20" is the motor max? And so in that case I shouldn't worry about having a battery that can output continuously 50a and then some to prolong the life?

## \#6059 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-19T07:58:15.965Z Reads: 70

```
If you read the specs, it'll usually say "X battery amps, Y motor amps." More battery current is always better - overbuilding results in wider safety margins and room to expand/upgrade in the future. I don't know what your build looks like, but if possible stay away from 4.x based ESCs - they have some known flaws that some manufacturers don't address.
```

## \#6107 Posted by: Sn4pz Posted at: 2019-04-20T18:37:12.872Z Reads: 75

```
It would help to show the power button, but I don't think that's your issue. 

With esk8 we typically use two types of on and off switches - antispark *loop keys* and antispark *switches*

In reality, you could just plug the vesc in everytime you want to ride but 

A) people say that the spark wears down the components

And B) you likely have everything under the board.... No one wants to disassemble their board everytime before they ride it 

That being said most antispark switches are poorly designed and break at completely 'random' intervals, and antispark loop keys are very very reliable, and when they break they're easily repairable and (I could be wrong here, can someone else confirm? -> ) they pose less of a danger to the board when they fail. 

Or you could be onto something... :face_with_monocle:
```

## \#6141 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-22T00:39:34.520Z Reads: 69

```
Theoretically, yes. Lower KV means more wraps of wire around the stators, which means more resistance, more heat, less power. Ideally you want the highest KV you can safely use without exceeding the ERPM limit of the controller.

On the flip side though, higher KV means higher ERPM, which can lead to higher switching and eddy current losses. 

I'd say you'll be fine either way. Unless you have a motor dyno to check those numbers, there's a chance of variation between motors, batches, and over time. 10% difference between the two isn't a deal breaker IMO.
```

## \#6182 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-04-23T06:16:02.003Z Reads: 75

```
[quote="ZachTetra, post:6181, topic:9559"]
Hypothetically, if I had 2 of the same motors and I connected them to a single wheel in a triangle, could I plug the ‘master’ motor with sensors into the ESC and splice the ‘slave’ motor into the phase leads?
[/quote]

```

## \#6183 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-23T07:05:53.776Z Reads: 72

```
In theory yes.

In theory you could run two motors from one ESC, but only if you had them locked together so they couldn't spin independently at all, and had them clocked right so the magnets and coils in each one were in exactly the same place and in phase with each other. In theory, it can be done. 

In practice, all bets are off. 

Only one way to find out! Go for it and post the results here!
```

---
## \#6184 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-23T07:07:50.082Z Reads: 75

```
[quote="MysticalDork, post:6183, topic:9559"]
only if you had them locked together so they couldn’t spin independently at all, and had them clocked right so the magnets and coils in each one were in exactly the same place and in phase with each other
[/quote]


This is the tricky part, and why you can't run motors on two wheels with one ESC, because they won't stay clocked unless they share a live axle.
```

## \#6268 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-25T06:43:50.349Z Reads: 70

```
Re: not feeling like sagging, it's possible that Boosted is doing something clever like dynamic current settings - increasing the maximum allowable current as the voltage drops, to keep the wattage constant.

Also LiFePO4 has a flatter discharge profile then LiPo and far flatter than Li-ion. Even though it sags, it probably doesn't sag as much proportionally when nearly dead as nearly full.
```

---
## \#6269 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-04-25T07:41:53.903Z Reads: 67

```
That was my thought as well.  It sags a lot, but the amount it sags when completely full is just about the same amount as when it's nearly dead.  (3.0V / cell under load, 3.0V to 3.65V / cell open-circuit)
```

---
## \#6270 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-25T08:00:32.851Z Reads: 75

```
Exactly. That's one of the places li-ion adds a lot of energy without adding a ton of capacity - especially the extreme high-energy-density (4.35v etc) variants really emphasize retaining the initial voltage for a while to maximize area under the curve, but as a result the whole line has a slope to it and falls off a lot near the end.![image|690x388](upload://nAlLwoExC6cEBAuPT0C96vN6s2H.png) ![image|690x388](upload://9UEzqJ3A5AXirpL9KbZ0U9yPNj.png) Top: Samsung 25R 2500mAh. Bottom: A123 26650M1A 2300mAh. Both tests at 15A.

That's also something that can make battery gauges difficult on LiFePO4 and other flat discharge chemistries - It's really hard to gauge a battery if it only drops 0.2v under load from 90% full to 90% dead.
```

## \#6282 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-26T02:57:36.286Z Reads: 67

```
Looks like that shaft has moved a little. Might want to check the setscrews at the back, and tap that shaft gently back until the circlip and shim are snug against the bearing again.

You can file down keys if  they're a tight fit - It's possible you have 1/8" (3.175mm) keys and 3mm keyways. It's pretty quick to take 0.175mm off with some sandpaper or a file. You can get away without a key if you use Loctite 680, but it's not best practice, and I like having  a physical piece of steel in there - it helps my peace of mind.
```

## \#6381 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-30T01:32:25.749Z Reads: 71

```
BoltDepot.com is an excellent source of hardware in the US, and often cheaper than McMaster. 

Since they're metric fasteners, you don't want grade 8. Metric strength grades aren't the same as imperial grades - Metric grade 8 is about equivalent to imperial grade 5. The metric equivalent to grade 8 is 10.9, and 12.9 is even stronger, equivalent to imperial L9 or A574. You want grade 10.9 or 12.9 hardware wherever possible.

Stainless is usually between 50 and 110K psi.

![image|211x500](upload://iCvK738RY5zNUw74rHUpCzoZVpi.png)
```

## \#6384 Posted by: Dirt_Bag Posted at: 2019-04-30T04:11:51.773Z Reads: 67

```
Check out this video for help. I used this method before but made the sides more narrow and not all the way to the edge of the board. It worked great and my enclosure is a perfect fit.

https://youtu.be/OdJWcsSZG4M
 
Just be warned, you need alot of patience to work with fiberglass. The sanding and body filler takes hours, but the end result is fantastic.

To make things easier, plane the enclosure flat with a long file and then fill with body filler and repeat. Once you have it looking good and smooth, wetsand in a tank of water or under a faucet up to about 400 grit is plenty. Paint with rustoleum filler/primer spray and then sand. Repeat until you are happy with the surface qaulity. Then cover it in something like rustoleum textured black paint. Its super tough and hides minor blemishes. If you scrape your enclosure just use body filler and repaint. This paint is fantastic for repairs. The entire part doesn't need a coat, just the damaged area.
```

## \#6390 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-30T06:33:02.526Z Reads: 66

```
If you're planning to tear out the batteries in the lights and drive them from the main pack, you might as well do it in one step by buying an LED driver, instead of making 9v and then losing more efficiency in the built in driver. [This one](https://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/MEAN-WELL/LDD-1500H?qs=sGAEpiMZZMt5PRBMPTWcaaGhWv0C5pBADOgZ2HjvIEt%252BC%252BX7QVaIag%3D%3D) is 1.5A and will take anything from 8 to 52v in, and feed any LED or string of LEDs with a forward voltage less than its input voltage. Less than $7, and up to 97% efficiency. You can run two of them in parallel if 1.5A per LED isn't enough.

(I don't think you'll need two in parallel, even with just one it'll be obnoxiously bright.)
```

## \#6403 Posted by: ZachTetra Posted at: 2019-04-30T19:41:22.127Z Reads: 67

```
motor voltage doesn't exceed  battery voltage so you will get less volts to a motor at 6s, which means less speed and less total power

Under the assumption that the theoretical amp draw (battery voltage over motor resistance) is greater than the 65A the motor is rated for, you will not see a difference in torque, if its less than 65A then it will have less kick
```

## \#6410 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-04-30T23:07:16.645Z Reads: 66

```
There is a pad on the BMS, labeled "C-". Your charging port, no matter what it is, needs to have the negative wire go to C-, and the positive wire go to the battery positive rail. It doesn't matter whether you use an XT plug, an XLR, barrel jack, whatever, as long as your charger has a mating plug.
```

## \#6436 Posted by: Andy87 Posted at: 2019-05-02T01:24:03.606Z Reads: 66

```
[quote="ShredRedwood, post:6435, topic:9559"]
how would I know if they’re already glued in already
[/quote]

As far as I remember the older tb motors not glued at all. If you use loctite it’s important that the loctite can run under the magnets. You can see if there is a small gap between bell and magnet it’s good to go. If there is a sealant in that gap like epoxy it’s not going to work.

I definitely would glue back the retainer ring with some epoxy. Just some drops and put it back.

The problem I see in the epoxy battle harden is that you need the right epoxy consistence to work good with. If it’s too fluent it’s run away if it’s too thick it doesn’t run in all corners. It’s also need a bit a time to get it right so that it’s not stuck on the magnets and will later hit the stator. I had good experience using a 5min epoxy. It’s enough time to fill up 2-3 gaps and remove the epoxy which came on the motors. In case you will do that one day, really get wooden popstickles. They help a lot to remove the epoxy from the magnets as the epoxy stuck to the wood better than plastic or metal.
```

## \#6438 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-05-02T02:12:03.972Z Reads: 68

```
I would not use silicone, like GE Silicone 2+ on motors.

I use acrylic conformal coating and silicone modified conformal coating.  Remember the silicone modified conformal coating traps heat, so use sparingly on the parts that get hot (windings & stator).

First I use the acrylic conformal coating on the motor sensors and anything else that has exposed metal.  Then I usually wait for it to dry and put a second and third coat on.  You can put it anywhere inside the motor except on the bearings, and it's extremely runny, so don't let ANY of it get in the bearings.

Next after that dries I go over it with silicone modified conformal coating mostly on the sensor assembly and where the phase leads connect to the windings and especially all the sensor wires.

But I am still trying to perfect my process.  I tried to put epoxy on the magnets once and it formed into the magnetic field and started sticking up then flowing onto the magnets so I quickly wiped it off.  I guess JB Weld has actual steel in it.
```

## \#6447 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-02T04:32:33.422Z Reads: 64

```
Yeah, it's definitely a deep rabbit hole to go down. Basically from my admittedly limited experience, if you want to print gorgeous photographs and hang them on your wall, go with a high end inkjet, they can do glossies like noone's business. For text and image documents of decent quality and good price, go toner. Yes, the toner cartridges cost more than ink cartridges, but they last a LOT longer before needing replacement.

Brother has several models of LED printer that can print color just as fast as black and white, and a lot faster than most inkjets. 
(It used to be that laser printers could only do b/w, or took like 4x as long to print in color compared to b/w, but the newer ones are much better.)

Laser printers are usually a little bit physically larger than inkjet, but IMO the cost per page outweighs the size difference.

## \#6488 Posted by: Dirt_Bag Posted at: 2019-05-03T05:46:43.458Z Reads: 65

```
Its simple to calculate. Your battery is 6ah. Your charger can charge at a rate of 2a. So you would charge in 3 hours, but this is not really possible with heat loss, inefficiency, and other factors. Add about 20% to that time and you have a reasonable charging time estimate so i would say 3.5 to 4 hours
```

## \#6500 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-03T08:29:54.284Z Reads: 68

```
I'd guess your multimeter and/or charger is not properly calibrated, and thus your batteries are just a tad overcharged. It's certainly not good for them, so I'd recommend going for a quick spin to bring that down to below 50.4. In general, I avoid keeping my batteries (flashlight, phone, laptop, vehicle) at 100% charge. I usually set my chargers to stop around 4.1-4.1-4.15/cell rather than the full 4.20. It improves the lifespan of the cells, and doesn't really cost you much range.
```

## \#6511 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-03T18:11:45.818Z Reads: 69

```
If you want strength, don't use stainless. Only use stainless if you **need** the corrosion resistance. Stainless has all kinds of issues like galling, and is not worth it for the "ooh, shiny" factor. If at all possible, buy class 10.9 or 12.9 alloy steel fasteners.
```

Never ever EVER use 316 stainless steel.

You need a thread lube for any application, and if you don't the threads will friction weld under any kind of torque.
```

## \#6555 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-04T21:22:35.635Z Reads: 61

```
Be careful with those button head screws - they're stronger, but the hex drive is a size smaller than the cap screws, so you'll be more likely to strip the drive than to break the screw. Using Wera hex-plus wrenches helps a lot, but there's only so much you can do when the drive is smaller. That's why I always recommend cap head screws where possible - much harder to strip them.
```

## \#6577 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-06T07:18:38.513Z Reads: 68

```
From my experience, nylon is a little more fussy to print, but results in a wonderfully tough and wear-resistant part. It is a little hygroscopic, but that shouldn't affect its performance as a pulley. PETG can be easier to print, but it's a little more brittle and not quite as tough.

My $0.02, if you can afford it and your printer can handle it, go nylon 100%.
```

## \#6585 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2019-05-06T19:46:52.321Z Reads: 71

```
Only do a re detect if you are absolutely certain there is nothing wrong with the motor.  Run a quick hand phase test on it to check theres nothing shorting out in there or you will brick your vesc with a detection.  

Let’s say the phase wires on the motor are A, B, and C

**Disconnect them from the ESC**

Touch A+B together. Verify the motor has choppy brakes

Touch A+C together. Verify the motor has choppy brakes

Touch B+C together. Verify the motor has choppy brakes

Touch A+B+C together. Verify the motor has SMOOTH brakes that are much stronger

All the choppy brakes should feel the same. If one is weaker or stronger or if anything isn’t as described above, it means you might have winding issues.
```

## \#6601 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-07T06:54:47.267Z Reads: 75

```
@ZachTetra @Dirt_Bag  You can also get other forms of locking nuts than nylock, and don't need that extra couple mm of engagement, such as flex-top and distorted-thread locknuts. McMaster has several flavors in stock, and I'm sure you could find other suppliers and styles. They're commonly used where either the service temperature (or environmental effects) would degrade the nylon insert, or where even tougher locking and vibration resistance is required. ## \#6737 Posted by: taz Posted at: 2019-05-08T07:00:52.914Z Reads: 71

```
Quick comparison.

I have tried sealed maytech 6355, 6374 both 190kv and sk8 6374 149kv.

There is no discernible difference between the 6355 and 6374 maytechs when set at the same amps. There is a big difference however in how fast they overheat.

When I had my Evo setup with 6355 they would overheat when on my way back home from work to the point I would have to get off the board and let them cool to continue.\
Now with the 6374 it is the focboxes that overheat and I end up having to do the exact same thing :rofl: . I have plans for an aluminium plate to help cool them though so this should be sorted.

When I had the 6374 maytechs on my Trampa that thing was a beast. Eventually they did overheat though whereas the vesc6 were at 45C (a part of this is due to better vesc placement).

When I changed to the 6374 sk8 149kv, I lost power and torque :thinking: . The sk8 are smoother though but on a MTB with bindings that is not so important.
```

## \#6799 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-09T20:59:36.457Z Reads: 64

```
In theory the closer you get to the hangar being vertical (90 degrees), the less mechanical advantage you have. So since yours are pretty close to 90 (45+20), you'll have a hard time overcoming the stiffness of the bushings. I'd recommend either getting some adjustable-angle trucks (I've seen them on here, but can't find them right now), or getting/making some angle blocks to cancel out some or all of that extra 20 degrees.
```

---
## \#6800 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-09T21:03:12.081Z Reads: 65

```
Ideally you'd want to have a key installed like @b264 mentioned to prevent rotation, and have the setscrew tightened down to prevent any side-to-side movement. Loctite is an option but not recommended on its own.

If you don't already own one, I strongly recommend acquiring a set of allen wrenches, specifically the Wera hex-plus ones. They're pricey, but absolutely worth every penny.
```

## \#6841 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-11T00:17:18.057Z Reads: 72

```
@Drom  Because with these motor controllers, "full throttle" is not always synonymous with "full current." 
Think of your car - Cruising down the highway at 70mph, are you using full throttle? No. Because even though you might have an engine capable of producing 500 horsepower, it only takes about 30-80 horsepower to cruise on the highway at 70mph.

The reason you want dual vescs at 80A is the same reason you'd prefer to drive a 500hp sportscar compared to a 100hp honda civic - acceleration. Sure, a civic can cruise at 70mph just as well as a sportscar , but you'll take a lot longer to reach that speed. It's also the reason it's harder to pass on the freeway with a gutless car - You have very little power left over for acceleration to pass, whereas a sportscar might still have 420 horsepower to spare, where your civic only has 20hp left over.

The difference in speed between 10A and 50A with no hills with gear ratio adjusted so you reach that current draw at your maximum possible RPM is significant. But either way, it'll be an incredibly shitty ride because your acceleration from a standstill will be so slow.

Conversely if you have them geared for the same speed, the 50A setting will feel amazing, because while they'll both **eventually** reach the same speed, the 50A one will do it in a small fraction of the time. 

The 50A setting and the 10A will also consume the same power at top speed. You only need the extra 40A for **acceleration**.
```

## \#6844 Posted by: Clonkex Posted at: 2019-05-11T00:54:57.463Z Reads: 70

```
It's also worth mentioning more current = more heat, which (aside from battery limitations) is the main reason we can't just pump 500A through our ESCs and motors. It's all a balancing act. You can often push way more current through a motor than it's rated for on a cold day, because it won't get too hot and melt something.
```

```
[quote="ZachTetra, post:6913, topic:9559, full:true"]
What would trigger protection mode?
[/quote]
**If your not bypassing:**

1. Running the battery too low. 
2. Drawing too much current. 
3. If a P-group or Lipo pack breaks loose or otherwise disconnects from the battery. 
4. If a short occurs in the battery or anywhere in the entire circuit.

## \#6937 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-14T02:53:27.899Z Reads: 71

```
The current rating is the amount that can pass through the BMS, not the amount the BMS can dissipate on its own. Most BMSs can dissipate between 20 and 200 milliamps per cell. 

If you want to use your BMS for discharge, then the current rating of your BMS should match the maximum discharge capability of your battery. For a 12s3p of (I'm assuming) 30Q cells, that would be 60A.
```

## \#6989 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-05-15T05:38:23.604Z Reads: 69

```
[quote="ZachTetra, post:6987, topic:9559"]
full coverage in all directions with 3/8 closed cell neoprene foam and a steel container with neutral cure silicone on all the edges and a printed adapter to silicone all the wires as a block, as long as the water doesn’t ingress through the wire I would chuck it in a pool
[/quote]

That's not waterproofing.

That's preventing water ingress -- aka making it water resistant.  That's good -- but it's not as good as waterproofing, and they are best combined together.  "Waterproof" means your whole enclosure and motors and everything can be full of water in a river and it still works.

Typically that's acheived by putting acrylic conformal coating all over all things
```

## \#6996 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-15T07:02:42.836Z Reads: 69

```
You can get thread inserts like this ![image|500x500](upload://6WTr2caP7k7x7sZtxbmcCZ6CagL.jpeg)  
that go in from the bottom, which will solve your ugly griptape problem. If you have a drill press or another way to drill to a specific depth, you might even be able to avoid having any holes that go all the way through to the top surface.

Those are available in many different styles for hard and soft wood, from many different sellers - be careful choosing the right ones.

"big enough" is relative, and depends on how many you use. I prefer M4, and for my enclosure (enclosure bearing full weight of electronics), I had them spaced out every 3-4" or so all around the perimeter. If you go with M3, you'll need a lot more to get the same strength.
```

## \#7029 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2019-05-16T19:22:51.094Z Reads: 65

```
First thing if you are talking about actual front wheel drive then it will give you a better hill climb ability but less traction in the wet.  Also braking in the wet is very hairy.  In the dry however it will give you more stopping power but this also can be a bit too much.  I have only every used a front drive board with urethane though.  One thing to consider too is if the board locks a motor then you are flying whether you like it or not.  Sometimes with rear drive if one wheel locks you can ride it out.
Rear drive reverse mount if you want to mount the trucks drop through because you will be able to lift your motors enough to clear the deck in most cases.
```

Seems like it should have an obvious solution, but I'm failing to find the bullet junction blocks that I would use for smaller wires like 20awg. So far the only solution I've found for 10awg wire is to just solder them all together in a big blob, which is not the solution I want to use!

## \#7080 Posted by: nirurin Posted at: 2019-05-18T02:02:33.845Z Reads: 71

```
No, but it does still need to junction to the main 10awg power line (at least according to the standard wiring diagram I am following from here...). 

So sure the charger wire can be smaller, but I'd still need a 10awg/10awg/16awg junction (or whatever I use for charger). 

Worryingly, I had got the idea for using 10awg from this site as I was generally told 12awg would be enough, but I decided to overengineer it a little and go with 10awg. Except now I learn that 10awg max safe amperage is 55amps, and my battery is 60amp max output. Not sure where this has gone awry.
```

---
## \#7081 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-18T02:57:34.256Z Reads: 72

```
The ampacity rating of a wire changes based on the temperature rating of the insulation and the maximum allowable voltage drop across the length of the wire. Silicone-insulated 200C 10AWG wire is good for about 120-130A, whereas regular Romex or whatever house-rated wire is only 60C, and is good to only 30A.

For a regular charging brick of 2-8A, 18-20AWG is fine.
As for connecting, if possible I'd just solder the small wire onto the pads where you soldered the big wire. 
If you don't have pads, but instead have a connector, you may be able to jam both the 10awg and smaller wire into that and solder them together that way.
```

---
## \#7082 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-05-18T04:44:08.106Z Reads: 69

```
This is all true to some extent.

I'd like to add that I normally try to err on the side of caution and don't exceed [these ratings](https://www.powerstream.com/Wire_Size.htm) -- which does put 10AWG at 55A continuous, 110A burst

You can use smaller wire but the losses and heating will be more, of course.
```

## \#7107 Posted by: ZachTetra Posted at: 2019-05-20T05:27:07.040Z Reads: 72

```
Can someone please explain how TKP and angled risers go together?  I found this MTB on Amazon, 35ish degree tilt with what look like normal TKP trucks on them...do mountain boards use different base plates or do they handle well at angles?
```

---
## \#7108 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-20T06:07:32.215Z Reads: 69

```
Mountainboard trucks usually are either zero degree, or adjustable. The angle comes from the deck, rather than the baseplate like skateboard trucks.

That's why if you want to run mtb trucks on a regular board, or regular trucks on a mtb, you need angled risers to either add in or remove angle to get the correct geometry.
```

---
## \#7109 Posted by: ZachTetra Posted at: 2019-05-20T06:18:22.251Z Reads: 68

So if I get TKPs and a MTB deck, I’ll get shitty handling?
```

---
## \#7110 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-20T06:22:31.135Z Reads: 70

```
If you don't have any angle blocks, the angle of the trucks (RKP or TKP) will add together with the angle of the deck, and you'll end up with something that barely turns at all when you put your weight on it.
```

## \#7148 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-20T17:18:49.588Z Reads: 71

```
The thermally sensitive part is where it's bolted to the heatsink. Desoldering the wires at their other end will be totally fine.

You can cut PCB with nippers, a fine tooth hack saw, or a dremel tool. Just be careful to avoid exposure to the fiberglass dust, and be aware that any non-abrasive tool will be dulled fairly quickly.
```

## \#7163 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2019-05-21T08:34:28.701Z Reads: 76

```
You have a bad bearing if the torque on the axle does not affect the rotation of the wheel.  Without or indeed with a short spacer as you tighten the wheel the two inner races will compress and put pressure on the outer thereby causing friction and slowing down the rotation.  Always better to ride with a larger spacer than a shorter and definitely don't ride with no spacers.
```

## \#7181 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-21T23:10:10.645Z Reads: 69

```
@ZachTetra I wouldn't recommend that method - Threads always have some play, and the holes in the trucks that you've driven your screws into will get looser and looser as they wear out, and eventually the screws will fail or the aluminum of the truck or mount will. 

@Rasta Building up a board with caliber or similar trucks will definitely be more expensive, but the result will be far better. If those trucks end up working, then great! If not, you can always pony up and buy better trucks and better mounts down the line when the first ones break. 

It's a matter of your personal build philosophy - do you make a cheap proof of concept first and then fix its issues, or but once, cry once?
```

## \#7252 Posted by: venom121212 Posted at: 2019-05-24T12:14:40.284Z Reads: 70

```
Honestly the ones you linked will work fine. Just being technical. If you have access to epoxy, id put a dab of it on the **outside** threads of the insert to make sure they stay in. 

1) let them fully cure before inserting bolts

2) don't get any epoxy inside the insert


Instead of trying to remember every drill bit size for every application, learn this one rule of thumb:

![choosing-a-drill-bit-size|500x500](upload://1uYotAAF77DPPDKMRXBfaRalG1U.jpeg)

In your case, the shank is still the insert minus the threads. If you don't have a perfect matched bit, use a slightly smaller one.
```

## \#7286 Posted by: b264 Posted at: 2019-05-25T19:53:41.937Z Reads: 77

I’m worried that whatever holds it in place won’t be strong and just plugging/unplugging the loopkeys will pull the connector out/push it into the case.

This is also a concern of mine.

I make holes with a file the exact shape of the male XT90 and use JB Weld to secure them.  I have 4 so far and none have broken loose.  You have to be very meticulous in how you do it, though, and you have to give the epoxy a FULL 30 hours to cure and do it in about 5 coats, ensuring it's mixed very well and in the proper ratio.  The first time is just 3 tiny drops to tack it in place, then wait 30 hours....

## \#7313 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-27T01:56:51.647Z Reads: 87

```
White is for a power switch, and the nub on the end of the black wires is a thermistor, designed to be tucked inside your pack to monitor the temperature of the cells.

## \#7318 Posted by: dareno Posted at: 2019-05-27T22:41:17.363Z Reads: 86

```
I think leaving it charging is a good starting point.  My 12s does this every 10 charges or so but it hovers around 95% for ages then shows 100 but stays red.  Fan stays on and the bms heats up.  Eventually it goes green and is good.  Try it first before you think about a strip down.

## \#7319 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-05-27T23:35:40.038Z Reads: 87

```
I'd just leave it charging for longer. Most BMSs have a pretty low balancing current (50mA isn't uncommon) so a large imbalance like that can take many hours or days to correct, depending on the capacity.
```

```
I wouldn't. 4mm bullets aren't that large so their current carrying capacity is limited, and that style of bullet connector (with the separate spring) is especially not great for high current.
```

## \#7359 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-03T01:42:43.945Z Reads: 80

```
I'd go with 5.5mm bullet connectors. Much beefier and most are a one-piece design without a separate spring.

(The spring adds another set of contact points and more chance for a high resistance connection, not good.)
```

## \#7360 Posted by: s5300 Posted at: 2019-06-03T01:52:15.283Z Reads: 78

```
The unity comes with 3.5mm connectors, and I'm building my rig with MR60's which are 3.5mm. He should be completely fine with them.

Maytech 6374 170kv are only rated for max 65A discharge. 3.5mm bullets are 30/piece I believe.
```

---
## \#7361 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-03T05:39:09.609Z Reads: 76

```
I don't totally disagree, but there are two points that would make me avoid them: 

1: bigger = better when it comes to wire and connectors unless you can't physically fit them.


2: the bullets with the separate springs have a known and documented tendency to make shitty or intermittent contact.

3.5mm solid bullets like the ones on MT60s are better IMO than 4mm or 5mm ones with separate springs.
```

## \#7362 Posted by: Dirt_Bag Posted at: 2019-06-03T06:00:04.829Z Reads: 73

```
That battery is simply enourmous and too big to fit on your board. With only 6s it will be extremely underwhelming.

If you go with 2 pf those to make 12s, you would obv need 2x the space. Splitting turnigy lipos is  impossible as well. The cells are glued together with permanent adhesive. You will break the fragile pouch and have a massive fire. Lipos in general should be avoided. They dont have the lifespan of an 18650 and they are much more dangerous
```

The vesc has a soft thermal protection feature - As it nears the danger zone, it will begin reducing its power output until it reaches equilibrium or the maximum allowable temperature, whichever comes first.

## \#7419 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-12T05:20:00.008Z Reads: 71

```
I'm gonna split this into two possible permutations:

Q1: Is it physically possible to to apply 12S (50 Volts) to the motor immediately from 0 RPM?

A1: Yes, but it will cause a ridiculous initial current draw due to the low resistance of the windings, possibly damaging the motor and/or the controller and/or the battery or BMS.

Q2: Can a Vesc do the above?

A2: I don't know, but I don't think you'd get THAT much more performance, considering the risk to your hardware. Also, with the ridiculous current, you'd saturate your stator (Once saturated, you get very little to no benefit to increased amperage).
```

## \#7421 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-12T07:02:04.258Z Reads: 74

```
Voltage does not directly affect torque. Torque in an electric motor is caused by the interaction of magnetic fields, at least one of which is from an electromagnet. The strength of the interaction (and thus torque) is proportional to the strength of the fields, and the strength of an electromagnet is a function of the number of turns of wire, times the number of amps. 

TLDR, more amps=more torque, until you saturate the steel in the stator. Voltage is only there to push the electrons around, generating the current.

The Vesc is usually in current-limiting mode, where it adjusts its output voltage to maintain the output current at or below the maximum set value. When a motor is stopped, the only thing stopping it from drawing infinite current is its own internal resistance (measured in miliohms) and the similarly low internal resistances of the VESC, BMS, wiring, and battery. Thus at low speed if you measure the voltage and current output of the VESC, if it's set at 50 motor amps and you floor it, it will shove 50 amps through the motor, but only like 8 volts. This is because any higher voltage would cause the motor to pass more than 50 amps.

This changes at higher speeds, due to a phenomenon called back-EMF, or generated voltage. As the motor spins, it behaves as a generator, producing a voltage that opposes the input. At some point the back-EMF and the input voltage match each other, and this is the point where the motor will not spin any faster - its maximum speed.  This is why esk8 and other vehicles powered by BLDC motors have a "hard limit" on top speed - it's not about available power like it is in a car, rather it's the point where the motor just will not spin faster because that would cause it to generate electricity rather than consume it.
```

## \#7422 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-12T07:04:39.798Z Reads: 72

```
An esk8 with a 6s battery, and an esk8 with a 12s battery (and all other hardware and settings identical) will accelerate the same from a dead stop. The 12s will **continue** accelerating for longer, and reach a higher top speed, but the 6s will launch just as hard.

This is the same thing that your battery current setting affects - not **how hard** you accelerate initally, but **for how long** that acceleration persists before tailing off.

Think of motor current as torque, and battery current as maximum horsepower. Raising your maximum horsepower won't necessarily increase your torque at launch, but you'll still win the race because you can keep accelerating longer.
```

## \#7426 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-13T04:47:35.419Z Reads: 76

```
The resistance of the motor doesn't increase, but the back-EMF (generated voltage) opposes the battery voltage more and more as speed increases, which makes the motor behave as if its resistance is changing.

The resistance is not directly related to torque or KV, merely a side effect. As I mentioned above, the strength of the magnetic field is proportional to the current times the number of turns. A lower KV motor (more torque) has more turns, and thus produces stronger magnetic fields per amp. But because wire has resistance, more turns means longer wire, which has a higher resistance.
```

## \#7451 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-14T03:14:29.146Z Reads: 78

```
@Sn4pz @cubed You could use USB-PD standard, which is up to 20v and 5A, for 100w. You would need an onboard module to convert from 20v/5A to battery voltage, and negotiate with your charger. 

I would not recommend just using any old connector (USB-C) and run any old voltage and current through it. That's how people end up with exploded electronics, or melted connectors. (USB is current limited to 500ma unless your device negotiates with the charger for more power. Your esk8 charger is not similarly limited.)
```

## \#7527 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-21T20:55:03.056Z Reads: 54

```
It really depends on the weight (thickness) of the fiberglass you're using. For an enclosure with no mechanical/structural loads on it other than its own mass, I'd say 1/16" (~1.5mm) should be more than sufficient. You'll have to figure out how many layers of fiberglass are needed to make up that thickness though.

Polyester resin can be used with vacuum impregnation, but it's not ideal for several reasons: It's really, really smelly and attacks many materials, such as rubber gloves. It's also hard to mix perfectly because the ratio of resin to hardener is so high (drops of hardener to ounces of resin), it's setup and curing time is very dependent on the temperature and the amount of hardener you used, and it is pretty viscous which makes vacuum impregnation even more problematic.

Having gone through this whole process myself, my recommendation is that you save yourself a lot of hassle and just buy some good low-viscosity epoxy resin online.
```

## \#7530 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-21T22:42:54.248Z Reads: 51

```
If you go forward with polyester, I'd recommend working somewhere cool or cold during the initial steps to make sure you get done with your layup before the resin starts to kick off, and also don't try to do vacuum infusion - Do a wet layup and then vacuum bag, because the resin is too thick to flow for infusion. Once you've got everything wet out and bagged, you can warm things up to speed up the hardening. 

Be aware that the volume of mixed resin has a great effect on pot life - a small scale batch will cure much slower than a large one. My last attempt at fiberglass with polyester was a partial failure because I mixed one big batch and it started to set up before I was ready.
```

## \#7537 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-06-22T03:06:26.346Z Reads: 64

```
Even ignoring the fact that this forum is primarily centered around electric skateboards, 

A: Lawnmower engines have vertical shafts, which are a pain to build any kind of vehicle with.

B: Lawnmower engines are governed and have shitty throttle response, making them a pain to build any kind of vehicle with.

C: Lawnmower engines have no clutch, making them a pain to build any kind of vehicle with.

D: A 10hp lawnmower engine is quite large and heavy, making it a pain to build a skateboard with.

E: Gas powered skateboards are illegal except on private property in many areas.
```

## \#7554 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-07-02T06:36:32.746Z Reads: 50

```
If you mean the thin (<0.5mm) glass screen protectors, then A: they're not tempered, and B: they're okay for a casual drop and scratches (I always have one installed), but I guarantee if you drop your phone at speed facedown or fall and land on it, you will have a broken screen.

As for hammer tested, hammers are generally smooth and that distributes the impact. A rock will break it much more easily (Guess how I know?).

And bulletproof? Don't make me laugh. The only thing it'd stop is an airsoft bb.

You've covered your bases as well as can be expected with a phone, but it's still just a vulnerable slab of glass, metal and plastic without any of the ruggedizing that goes into an action camera, even a cheap one.
```

## \#7558 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-07-02T20:59:10.521Z Reads: 57

```
For maximum range in a small package, cylindrical cells (18650, 2170, 26650) are the way to go - much more energy per unit volume than lipo pouches. 

You want torque, and the best way to get torque is to gear low. Most boards with regular wheels (not pneumatic) have something like a 2.4:1 reduction, so going up to like 2.8 will improve hill-climbing. 
Runing an extra-low-KV motor will also help (the usual is 190, but you can find 170 and 140 sometimes), as will having a beefy motor and speed controller to handle lots of amps for low-end grunt.

@b264 has a bit of a fetish for boards with a kicktail, so I bet he can point you towards an appropriate deck, enclosure, battery, etc.

For a shorty board with a big battery, you may end up running out of space for the motor under the board, in which case reverse mounting it is an option, but it may be tricky with a kicktail.

While battery backpack is something that has been done before, it's usually either a last resort or an experiment due to the multiple drawbacks of such a setup, such as voltage spikes from long wires, danger of entanglement or inadvertent disconnection, increased risk of shorts or battery damage in a fall, and having an angry, flaming battery attached to you in the case of a fire.
```

```
[quote="kottelett, post:7569, topic:9559"]
I also red that hubs can be pushed around like a regular skateboard
[/quote]

This is a myth spread by marketing departments at companies that sell shitty skateboards.  Hub motors and belt drive both have resistance.  Gear drive has less than belt.

The good thing about belt is that if you have to, you can cut the belt off with a pocket knife and have ZERO resistance because it IS a regular skateboard.  (not the case for any other drive)  Then it's a four dollar, four minute fix once you get home.

Don't use hubs unless you use [Hummie Hubs](https://forum./t/hummie-hubs-kickstarter/2540).  No other hubs.

## \#7575 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-07-06T19:52:47.451Z Reads: 59

```
If you're looking for lots of range in a small package, LiFePO4 is not the chemistry for you. It is safer and very power-dense, but very lacking in energy density compared to 18650s. (LiFePO4 18650: 30A, 3.63wh. Regular 18650: 20A, 10.8wh.)

You will need more than ten 18650 cells. Probably the minimum viable is 20 (10s2p), and more is better, both for more range and better power for climbing hills.

I hate to say it but it sounds like you're chasing a unicorn - Tiny build with lots of range and hill climbing ability is very difficult. 

Even the build B264 linked which you said is too big only has "About 12 miles (19.3km) at low speed on flat, dry terrain on a warm day is best-case range I think. Real life range probably closer to 8.5 miles (13.7km) or 5 miles (8km) if you’re mashing the throttle."
```

## \#7584 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-07-09T00:28:26.048Z Reads: 56

```
The 4.12 is really badly designed for easy cooling. Your idea would help some, but for anything better I'd recommend one of the 6.x based vescs with directfets and an aluminum heat spreader/heatsink built in. You can pass that through the enclosure or sandwich heatsinks on the outside of the enclosure to conduct heat that way.

Be careful with your heatsinks if you go that route, it's really easy to accidentally short something out.

## \#7585 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-07-09T00:42:42.963Z Reads: 58

```
Gear drive is heavier, more expensive. Belt drive is lighter, cheaper, simpler. (I am speaking in generalities here.)

Gear drives usually has lower rolling resistance depending on the oil/grease and other factors.

Depending on the exact design, gear drive can be very quiet or quite loud. Belts are usually medium-quiet.

Gear drive usually needs to be enclosed to keep the rocks and dirt out, and keep lubrication in. Belt drive usually tolerates debris very well.

If a belt fails, you can replace it and be on your way. If one of your gears breaks/strips, you need a whole new gear or maybe both.

There are several gear drive options, but for the most part belt drives are better for low ratios (2:1, 3:1) where gear drives really have the advantage with higher ratios (4:1, 5:1).

Given the increased size, weight, cost, and higher ratios, gear drives are most commonly designed for mountainboards, rather than regular street boards. Some examples are [Kaly.NYC](https://www.kaly.nyc/product-page/helical-gear-drive-1-4) and [3DServisas](https://shop.3dservisas.eu/collections/drivetrain/products/fatboy-ss-drive-hd?variant=20235926765661).
```

## \#7624 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-07-17T19:41:26.422Z Reads: 46

```
That's a great material for for thickening resins, but for battle hardening you really don't need much thickening. Just fill any gaps between and behind the magnets, and then coat your windings. For the gap filling between the magnets you might want some thickening, but behind them, and for coating the windings, a thinner resin is actually helpful.

You also need to waterproof the sensor PCB, and usually that's best done with a conformal coating, rather than an epoxy resin.
```
