## \#7629 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-07-17T21:50:58.268Z Reads: 46

```
Yes, it is recommended to use fish paper between cells. Kapton is very heat resistant but not abrasion resistant, and the biggest danger of shorting between cell groups is vibration causing the plastic wrap to break through that way.

The discharge wires should be sized for whatever your maximum discharge current will be - 12AWG or 10AWG is good. Your balance wires should be about 22AWG. (anything between 18-24AWG really.)

You should have ten blocks, each with four cells in parallel. If you go the other way, you'll just be making it harder to wire together properly.

You should use heat shrink and fish paper primarily. Kapton is too thin and prone to abrasion to use as the sole insulating layer. I tend to put kapton under places where I have to solder near the cells so any stray solder won't burn through and wreak havoc.

Don't try to solder directly to your cells. Use a bus bar or connection PCB, and solder your tabs to that.
```

## \#7667 Posted by: wafflejock Posted at: 2019-07-25T21:05:01.066Z Reads: 56

```
There's also a calculator linked (header banner) from forum dot esk8 dot news.  Generally speaking under 60k eRPM is limit, for typical 7 pole pair or 14 pole motor we use the max kv can be computed as 60,000/7 = 8500, 8500 / battery voltage = max kv motor to use.  Say you have 50V battery 8500/50 = 170 (rounding)

Also most components on VESCs are rated max 60V but more headroom you leave less likely a big spike causes an issue.

Edit corrected URL for other site.
```

## \#7682 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-07-30T22:07:59.444Z Reads: 55

```
@Sig0431  The only things to worry about are A: make sure the switch can handle the current you're running through it. B: make sure the voltage rating is equal or higher than what you plan to run. (These can both be fudged to some extent, with a corresponding loss of longevity.) C: if your switch is lighted, make sure you feed the light the correct voltage - some are 12v, and some are 120v. It won't hurt to run less, but your lighting will be either dim or nonexistant. Do not run higher.
```

## \#7699 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-08-15T04:42:22.549Z Reads: 51

```
@Drom The vesc just won't power up at all with a 1s battery. Maybe with a 2s, but definitely with a 3s.

@infiniteoffset Generally it's considered best practice for all the stuff in your enclosure to be mounted to the board, not the enclosure, that way the enclosure doesn't have to support the additional weight. Straps, screws, velcro, double-sided tape, all are acceptable for various degrees of permanence.  

@burke Define "good power." Define "good range." 
For the same result, DIY is almost always not cheaper than just buying a finished board - you will break stuff, you will need extra tools, extra materials, etc. If the backfire x2 looks like what you want and you just want to have a board, I'd suggest just buying it and be done. 
If you go DIY, you must be prepared to spend a lot of time reading, researching, building, rebuilding, and generally faffing about until you have something that works - a month late and 50% overbudget. If this sounds like a fun time to you, then I'd suggest taking a dive through [this thread.](https://forum./t/is-diy-right-for-you/112/2) It goes into great detail.
```

## \#7715 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-08-16T06:37:19.154Z Reads: 46

```
If you've got it set to L 10 and it's still not working, I dunno what to tell you. I'd play around with different settings and see if I could get a decent reading out of it somehow.

It's possible that it's calibrated for lipo rather than cylindrical li-ion cells - lipos usually only like to be discharged down to ~3.6-3.7v, and cylindrical cells can go down to 3.0 or lower, so that may be the reason for your issue - it sees 36v (divided by ten series cells = 3.6/cell) and calls that 0% instead of 40%.

This is why on my board, I just used a straight voltage meter and did the math in my head to estimate % from that - you can change the math in your head if it ends up being wrong.
```

---
## \#7733 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-08-22T18:56:52.626Z Reads: 52

```
@Sn4pz  As long as the ratio of teeth is the same, the actual number doesn't matter at all. 16:36 is the same as 27/60.

Since 3m belts have smaller teeth, they have to be tighter to prevent skipping, and need to have more teeth engaged than with 5m belts to transfer the same power. Keep this in mind when picking pulleys.
```

## \#7760 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-09-06T18:10:54.381Z Reads: 50

```
@AlvinB  Here's my breakdown of motors for single and dual, ordered by least to most fun/power.
 * Single 5055 or 5065: Boo!
 * Single 6355: Meh
 * Single 6374: Great!
 * Dual 5055: Okay
 * Dual 5065: Better
 * Dual 6355: Awesome!
 * Dual 6374: Overkill!

It all depends on your needs/requirements. Smaller motors are lighter and cheaper. Bigger motors handle more power for longer without overheating. More aggressive riding styles generally benefit the most from bigger motors, e.g. mountainboards with pneumatic wheels.
Keep in mind that big motors (63xx) need bigger vescs and a significant battery to really unlock their full potential - a regular 4.xx vesc with nothing but heat shrink tubing on it just will not cut the mustard.
```

```
@AlvinB  The Torqueboards kit is pretty decent. You can definitely shop around and find good deals, but of course if you do that you're more at risk of not getting everything to fit perfectly. It really depends on how much you value your time and how confident you are in your ability/stubbornness to reach an acceptable result.

Just like motors, battery selection is a judgement call. I would caution you about going with 12S if you don't need it, just because it's more stress on the system - 10S is usually fine for most builds. I will reiterate though: **if you have big motors, you need a bigger battery to feed them.** 12s2p will only give you a maximum of 20 battery amps per motor - that's great for a dinky dual 5065 build, but comically small for a dual 6374.

You seem not to have internalized the One Great Truth of DIY esk8: **ESK8 is expensive. Large powerful dual-6374 esk8, is VERY expensive.** Be prepared to spend upwards of $1000 on a full build. **There is *NO GUARANTEE* that building a DIY will be cheaper than buying a premade.** If you don't love building stuff for the sake of building stuff, this may not be for you.
```

```
If you read more carefully, it clearly says:
* **LIPO/LiFe - 1-6S**
* **NiMH/NiCd - 1-15S**

Your 12s battery is **NOT** a NiMh/NiCd, it is li-ion. That charger will only charge li-ion type batteries of **1-6S**. Therefore you cannot charge your 12s battery with this 6s charger.

Read more, kids. It really does help.
```

## \#7773 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-09-08T17:49:26.768Z Reads: 50

```
Nope, won’t work. The maximum voltage output of a 6s charger is ~25 volts (6x4.2). To charge your 12s pack, you need double that: 12x4.2, or 50.4 volts.

NiMh/NiCd batteries have a much lower cell voltage - 1.5 vs 3.7 for Li-ion cells. That means for the same given maximum voltage the charger can put out, you can have more in series - 15 in this case. (Hey look, since math is commutative, 15 times 1.5 is 22.5 volts! Almost identical to the voltage required to charge a 6s lipo!)

To charge a 12s li-ion pack, you need either a 12s-capable balance charger (you can get them, but they're stupid expensive) or a 12s brick charger.
```

## \#7775 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-09-10T01:39:23.263Z Reads: 49

```
@KadenKross  Because the absolute **do-not-exceed** voltage of the vescs we use is 60v, and the voltage of a fully-charged 13s battery is 54.6v, which leaves very little room for error or voltage spikes. It's a reliability thing. 

It's the reason many people stick to 10s: 12s is still pretty close to the limit. 

Unless you have some special high-voltage ESC, I strongly recommend against going with 12s or 13s until you have a much stronger grasp of the hobby and more experience with electric vehicles in general. 

This is serious shit. Best case scenario you blow out your vesc and have to limp home and spend money on a new one. Worst case, your vesc shits itself, you streetface and break bones, and your board catches on fire. Do not take this lightly.
```

## \#7827 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-09-21T20:37:41.285Z Reads: 64

```
@KadenKross 

[quote="KadenKross, post:7826, topic:9559"]
 I’m unclear about what is different about a Vesc.
[/quote]
Compared to a regular brushless ESC suc has those used for remote controlled airplanes and the like, the main difference is adjustability/customization. You can tweak just about every parameter in a vsc - battery current, motor current, acceleration curve, sensors, sensorless, BLDC or FOC (If you have one that supports FOC), maximum speed limit, switching frequency, traction control, the list goes on. 

With a "dumb" RC ESC, generally the most you can change is the voltage cutoff and maybe the braking behavior, and the brakes vary from nonexistent to terrible to screechy or locked-up-completely.

Compared to a brushed controller, the difference is even wider - I could build a brushed motor controller with those specs for maybe $25 because it's **really** dumb - basically it just interprets throttle and outputs PWM to the motor through a half-bridge. A $0.25 microcontroller, a $5 PCB and $15 in power switching components has you 90% there.

[quote="KadenKross, post:7826, topic:9559"]
I am having difficulty finding a definitive answer / solution as to wether I should build 2x6s or 7s. Or. 1x13s.and if I should use bms’s or a balance charger
[/quote]

It really all depends on your specific application and parameters - What's your maximum budget? Maximum space? What kinds of motor can you find? How good are you at fabrication? Does this have to be a reliable workhorse, or do you not care if it breaks after 500m? 

I still *strongly* recommend not exceeding 10S or at most 11S on this first build. If you go much lower, then to get high power output you need very high currents, and if you go any higher, the risk of a catastrophic failure increases.
```

## \#7849 Posted by: sesat Posted at: 2019-09-26T18:28:56.187Z Reads: 67

```
This is a known issue with non-OEM M365/M365pro dashboards. The boards are wired to deliver power to the LED headlamps on command, but the components on board can't actually deliver the juice. Instead, when you flip the lights on, the entire dashboard shuts off. The ideal solution is to use OEM dashboards, but the workaround is to accept the design flaw for what it is. I don't see how downgrading the firmware of the dashboard, speed controller, or battery management system would help. If you're not able to recover from the changes you've made, I'd suggest replacements that are entirely OEM or entirely open source, but nothing in between. Also, I suggest posting future questions on [https://forum.](https://forum./) since you never know when the helpful response you're relying on here gets deleted.
```

## \#7869 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-11-04T09:49:21.343Z Reads: 43

```
@Hoaz 
Yes, definitely redo that, it's absolutely not safe.

Some pointers: 
It looks like you've got a very cold solder joint. Either your iron is not hot enough, or if it is hot enough it doesn't have enough thermal mass/thermal transfer ability to heat up your joint enough. Just judging by that plug, I'd guess you've got a ~20-25W "pencil" style iron with no adjustment - if so, you will basically never get a good joint on larger wires using that type of iron, they're only suitable for small stuff. 

Bare minimum in my opinion is a variable-wattage iron like **[this one](https://www.amazon.com/Soldering-Iron-Station-Solder-Kit/dp/B07S5PZTFZ)** with at least 40 to 60 watts, and a fairly beefy tip - not one of those fine pointy conical ones, you want either a chisel or a bevel. Expect to pay at least $30. 

Ideally I'd recommend a variable-temperature (actually measures and controls the temperature, not just the power) soldering station, such as a Weller or Hakko, or a [knockoff](https://www.amazon.com/YIHUA-Professional-Digital-Soldering-Station/dp/B07RVMZNYR), or a [TS100](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01MD12DYT) - Expect to pay at least $50-80.

You also added way too much solder, probably in an attempt to overcome the lack of sufficient heat.

It also really helps to have the connector plugged into another (that's not wired to anything obviously), to keep the metal bits from shifting inside the plastic housing while everything is hot.
```

## \#7878 Posted by: mjaffee Posted at: 2019-11-18T05:45:21.843Z Reads: 36

```
A good first try, here's some tips. Make sure you have a large solder tip since it makes transmitting the heat a little easier for large wire connections. If you melt the plastic, things are getting too hot and you should let it cool before attempting again. 
1) Apply flux to the inside of the XT60 connector pins first
2) Heat up the pin and add a good bit of solder until the pin is 1/4 to 1/2 full of solder
3) Tin the wire making sure the solder goes down into the wire
4) Hold the tinned wire in the pin (with the solder pool) and apply the soldering iron where the pin and wire meet. Continue heating around the connection until the two fuse. More solder may be required. Allow to cool completely before adding the heat shrink.
```

## \#7880 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2019-11-25T06:18:00.359Z Reads: 28

```
Battery gauges that rely on reading voltage aren't accurate under changing load conditions. During charge the voltage across the battery will rise, causing the meter to read a higher state of charge. During discharge, the opposite will happen. 

This means that if your battery meter is calibrated and accurate under no-load conditions, you can't expect it to read correctly or accurately under either charge or discharge, only under no load.
```

## \#7912 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2020-02-15T06:14:18.652Z Reads: 9

```
[quote="Yarden, post:7904, topic:9559"]
What happens if you don’t have a power switch and keep the Vesc always plugged in to the battery?
[/quote]
You will slowly drain your battery, and if you let it go on for long enough, you will irreparably damage your battery.

[quote="Yarden, post:7904, topic:9559"]
How come a cheap 50$ ESC can do dual motor control + have its own dedicated remote control with battery indicating + have a power button + have auto ON/OFF switch integration, while the super sophisticated (expensive) VESC doesn’t?
[/quote]
Because you're paying for other things in a vesc, like the ability to tweak all the settings, and the safety features like overtemperature protection, and FOC, and and and.

[quote="Yarden, post:7904, topic:9559"]
why do I need a 50$ anti spark button to hardwarely disconnect the vesc from the batteries all the time?
[/quote]
You don't need to. You can use a $10 XT90-S loop key.

[quote="Yarden, post:7904, topic:9559"]
Does the VESC never goes to sleep? whats the wattage drawback of the VESC while on idle? If its neglectable, can I simply leave it plugged in all the time?
[/quote]
The vesc does not got to sleep, it's always running. Its idle current draw depends on several factors, including but not limited to the battery voltage, the exact hardware version of the vesc, the exact firmware version it's running, the exact settings you've got in in, and the phase of the moon.

Don't chance it. I recommend making up a loop key and being done with it. It's cheap, simple, and robust.

[quote="Yarden, post:7906, topic:9559, full:true"]
no no no…

a. its ugly

b. its not convenient

c. its not safe, exposed port a.k.a troubles caller

d. its not really that cheap, 10$ for the plug set, another 8-10$ for the mounted plug… and this link is surely expensive… now 3D printing stuffs? yeah… no!

e. with my soldering skills I’m sure not gonna make it solid enough for daily plugging and pulling…
[/quote]
Well, then maybe you see now why people think it's reasonable to charge $50 for a finished, not-"ugly", not-"inconvenient", not-exposed, not-dependent-on-your-soldering-skills antispark switch! What a concept! :upside_down_face:

I hate to break it to you, but if you got into the DIY esk8 world to save money, you've got another think coming. Either you accept that you cannot place a monetary value on your time and effort, or you spend extra money to have things done by other people so you don't have to. Things will break, and you will have to fix/replace them. Tools (like a decent soldering iron and related accessories) are required, and they cost money. Skills (like soldering) are required, and those take time to learn.
Unless you already have all the tools and skills necessary, DIY is rarely faster or cheaper than buying a premade thing.
```

## \#7922 Posted by: MysticalDork Posted at: 2020-02-15T10:44:53.268Z Reads: 8

```
[quote="Yarden, post:7920, topic:9559"]
posted some idea of a 3 position switch in the forum
[/quote]

Yeah, I saw that.

It would work, but your main issue by far will be finding a switch that can handle the 50+ amps we routinely draw from our batteries, in an economical and physically small package - Most that fit the electrical requirements will be physically large, and quite expensive to boot. There's a reason we as a community have settled on loopkeys: They're the cheapest, simplest, most robust and reliable solution to a thorny problem. No mosfets to blow, and if you do manage to fry the one resistor, it's a handful of dollars and a half hour of time to make a whole new one.

And if you do decide to go that route, I have a 3d printer and would be happy to print you out a mounting flange or other small accessories, for the cost of a few grams of filament plus shipping.
```
